{"uri": "8259298952", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:09:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:09:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:07:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.abc15.com/sports/paris-2024-olympics/belgium-withdraws-from-mixed-relay-triathlon-after-athlete-who-swam-in-seine-river-falls-ill", "title": "Belgium withdraws from mixed relay triathlon after athlete who swam in Seine River falls ill", "body": "Claire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement. (Scripps News)\n\nBelgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement.\n\nParis 2024 organizers had no immediate statement on Michel's illness, but said in a statement Sunday night that the mixed relay triathlon would proceed Monday at 8 a.m. The swim portion of the competition is slated for the Seine.\n\nThe Belgian committee's statement did not elaborate on Michel's illness but it comes after concerns over the river's water quality. Organizers had said that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nOn Sunday night, representatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities reviewed water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over recent hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon.\n\nRELATED STORY | E. coli in Seine River forces postponement of Olympic men's triathlon event\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli, in the Seine's waters. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nWorld Triathlon's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection and the weather forecast when determining whether to go forward with a race. The decisions have generally been made at early morning meetings on the day of the event. But in announcing Sunday night that the race would happen Monday, organizers said they were responding to requests from athletes to give them more time to prepare.\n\nLeading up to the individual triathlon events, water quality concerns prompted organizers to cancel the swimming portion of two test runs meant to allow athletes to familiarize themselves with the course and also to delay the men's race by a day. Test swims in the Seine scheduled for Saturday and Sunday before the triathlon mixed relay were also canceled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nThe Belgian committee said it \"hopes that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games. We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, entourage and supporters.\"\n\nRELATED STORY | Olympics triathlon practice canceled due to Seine River water quality concerns\n\nSwiss officials said Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who also competed in the Seine on Wednesday, fell ill with a stomach infection. But they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to the swim and that the other delegations told them none of their triathletes had reported stomach problems.\n\nSwiss officials said in an update Sunday that Simon Westermann, who had been tapped to replace Briffod, also had to withdraw because of a gastrointestinal infection. Westermann had not participated in any swims in the Seine, the statement said. The Swiss team still planned to compete in the mixed relay Monday.\n\nNorwegian triathlete Vetle Bergsvik Thorn got sick a day after competing in the men's triathlon. Thorn told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that he woke up the next day with an upset stomach and was vomiting but thought that the likely cause was food poisoning. He said he felt better later that day and was planning on competing again in the mixed relay scheduled for Monday.\n\nArild Tveiten, the sports director of the Norwegian Triathlon Federation, said the cause of Thorn's illness was unclear.\n\n\"We're thinking what everyone is thinking: that it's probably the river. But we don't know. It could be the river, it could be the chicken,\" Tveiten told NRK. \"The doctor is leaning toward the possibility of food poisoning. That's what the symptoms suggest.\"\n\nMarathon swimming events are set to be held in the Seine on Thursday and Friday.\n\nFive of the eight swimmers in the men's 1,500-meter freestyle Sunday night were listed to be entered in the 10-kilometer marathon swim.\n\nBronze medalist Daniel Wiffen of Ireland, who won an earlier gold in the 800 free, said he wouldn't train ahead of time in the Seine: \"I don't want to try to deal with any illness.\"\n\nHe said he would instead train in pools around Paris, even if it means \"going in blind.\"", "source": {"uri": "abc15.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8259215884", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "00:04:21", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T00:04:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T00:03:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/belgium-withdraws-from-mixed-relay-triathlon-after-athlete-who-swam-in-seine-falls-ill", "title": "Belgium withdraws from mixed relay triathlon after athlete who swam in Seine falls ill", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement.\n\nParis 2024 organizers had no immediate statement on Michel's illness, but said in a statement Sunday night that the mixed relay triathlon would proceed Monday at 8 a.m. The swim portion of the competition is slated for the Seine.\n\nREAD MORE: Olympic organizers to triathletes: Come on in, the Seine water is fine\n\nThe Belgian committee's statement did not elaborate on Michel's illness but it comes after concerns over the river's water quality. Organizers had said that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nOn Sunday night, representatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities reviewed water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over recent hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli, in the Seine's waters. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nWorld Triathlon's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection and the weather forecast when determining whether to go forward with a race. The decisions have generally been made at early morning meetings on the day of the event. But in announcing Sunday night that the race would happen Monday, organizers said they were responding to requests from athletes to give them more time to prepare.\n\nLeading up to the individual triathlon events, water quality concerns prompted organizers to cancel the swimming portion of two test runs meant to allow athletes to familiarize themselves with the course and also to delay the men's race by a day. Test swims in the Seine scheduled for Saturday and Sunday before the triathlon mixed relay were also canceled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nREAD MORE: Triathlon cancels Olympic swim training for the second day over Seine water quality concerns\n\nThe Belgian committee said it \"hopes that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games. We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, entourage and supporters.\"\n\nSwiss officials said Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who also competed in the Seine on Wednesday, fell ill with a stomach infection. But they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to the swim and that the other delegations told them none of their triathletes had reported stomach problems.\n\nSwiss officials said in an update Sunday that Simon Westermann, who had been tapped to replace Briffod, also had to withdraw because of a gastrointestinal infection. Westermann had not participated in any swims in the Seine, the statement said. The Swiss team still planned to compete in the mixed relay Monday.\n\nNorwegian triathlete Vetle Bergsvik Thorn got sick a day after competing in the men's triathlon. Thorn told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that he woke up the next day with an upset stomach and was vomiting but thought that the likely cause was food poisoning. He said he felt better later that day and was planning on competing again in the mixed relay scheduled for Monday.\n\nArild Tveiten, the sports director of the Norwegian Triathlon Federation, said the cause of Thorn's illness was unclear.\n\n\"We're thinking what everyone is thinking: that it's probably the river. But we don't know. It could be the river, it could be the chicken,\" Tveiten told NRK. \"The doctor is leaning toward the possibility of food poisoning. That's what the symptoms suggest.\"\n\nMarathon swimming events are set to be held in the Seine on Thursday and Friday.\n\nFive of the eight swimmers in the men's 1,500-meter freestyle Sunday night were listed to be entered in the 10-kilometer marathon swim.\n\nBronze medalist Daniel Wiffen of Ireland, who won an earlier gold in the 800 free, said he wouldn't train ahead of time in the Seine: \"I don't want to try to deal with any illness.\"\n\nHe said he would instead train in pools around Paris, even if it means \"going in blind.\"\n\nAssociated Press journalists Karl Ritter and Janie {"uri": "2024-08-444029207", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:35:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:35:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:32:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-belgium-withdraws-from-mixed-relay-triathlon-after-athlete-who-swam-in-seine-river-falls-ill-6164032.html", "title": "Sports News | Belgium Withdraws from Mixed Relay Triathlon After Athlete Who Swam in Seine River Falls Ill", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River fell ill.\n\nParis, Aug 5 (AP) Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement.\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024: Noah Lyles Takes Away Gold Medal by Whisker in Men's 100-Meter Final.\n\nParis 2024 organizers had no immediate statement on Michel's illness, but said in a statement Sunday night that the mixed relay triathlon would proceed Monday at 8 a.m. The swim portion of the competition is slated for the Seine.\n\nThe Belgian committee's statement did not elaborate on Michel's illness but it comes after concerns over the river's water quality. Organizers had said that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024: India To Take On Germany in Semifinals of Men's Hockey.\n\nOn Sunday night, representatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities reviewed water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over recent hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli, in the Seine's waters. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nWorld Triathlon's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection and the weather forecast when determining whether to go forward with a race. The decisions have generally been made at early morning meetings on the day of the event. But in announcing Sunday night that the race would happen Monday, organizers said they were responding to requests from athletes to give them more time to prepare.\n\nLeading up to the individual triathlon events, water quality concerns prompted organizers to cancel the swimming portion of two test runs meant to allow athletes to familiarize themselves with the course and also to delay the men's race by a day. Test swims in the Seine scheduled for Saturday and Sunday before the triathlon mixed relay were also canceled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nThe Belgian committee said it \"hopes that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games. We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, entourage and supporters.\"\n\nSwiss officials said Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who also competed in the Seine on Wednesday, fell ill with a stomach infection. But they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to the swim and that the other delegations told them none of their triathletes had reported stomach problems.\n\nSwiss officials said in an update Sunday that Simon Westermann, who had been tapped to replace Briffod, also had to withdraw because of a gastrointestinal infection. Westermann had not participated in any swims in the Seine, the statement said. The Swiss team still planned to compete in the mixed relay Monday.\n\nNorwegian triathlete Vetle Bergsvik Thorn got sick a day after competing in the men's triathlon. Thorn told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that he woke up the next day with an upset stomach and was vomiting but thought that the likely cause was food poisoning. He said he felt better later that day and was planning on competing again in the mixed relay scheduled for Monday.\n\nArild Tveiten, the sports director of the Norwegian Triathlon Federation, said the cause of Thorn's illness was unclear.\n\n\"We're thinking what everyone is thinking: that it's probably the river. But we don't know. It could be the river, it could be the chicken,\" Tveiten told NRK. \"The doctor is leaning toward the possibility of food poisoning. That's what the symptoms suggest.\"\n\nMarathon swimming events are set to be held in the Seine on Thursday and Friday.\n\nFive of the eight swimmers in the men's 1,500-meter freestyle Sunday night were listed to be entered in the 10-kilometer marathon swim.\n\nBronze medalist Daniel Wiffen of Ireland, who won an earlier gold in the 800 free, said he wouldn't train ahead of time in the Seine: \"I don't want to try to deal with any illness.\"\n\nHe said he would instead train in pools around Paris, even if it means \"going in blind.\" (AP)", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-08-443889805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:37:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:37:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:19:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/belgium-drops-out-of-mixed-triathlon-and-switzerland-shuffles-line-up-after-athletes-fall-ill/article_d51d0ac0-c9bd-5e9c-acdc-f4dc5c1f80e7.html", "title": "Belgium drops out of mixed triathlon and Switzerland shuffles line-up after athletes fall ill following race in River Seine", "body": "Athletes dive into the River Seine to start the swimming stage of the men's individual triathlon at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games on July 31.\n\nParis (CNN) -- Belgium has withdrawn from the mixed relay triathlon race on Monday and Switzerland has had to mix up its roster after athletes from both countries fell ill following the initial triathlon races last week.\n\nBelgium announced it was dropping out of the race after one of its triathletes, Claire Michel, has fallen ill, its National Olympic Committee said in a statement. The statement did not specify Michel's illness, which was reported days after she swam in the River Seine during the women's triathlon on Wednesday.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon must unfortunately announce that the 'Belgian Hammers' will not be starting the mixed relay at the Paris Olympic Games tomorrow. The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's triathlon competition on Wednesday.\n\nThe statement also had pointed words that appeared to be aimed at organizers: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games such as guaranteeing training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes and support personnel.\"\n\nThe Swiss team, meanwhile, had to replace Adrien Briffod, who had to withdraw due to a gastrointestinal infection. Simon Westermann will replace him.\n\nSwiss Olympic Chief Medical Officer Hanspeter Betschart noted that it is unclear if Briffod's infection is related to the Seine's water quality.\n\n\"A survey of my colleagues from other countries has so far not revealed any accumulation of gastrointestinal illnesses among the athletes who started the individual race last Wednesday,\" Betschart said.\n\nMixed relay triathlon to proceed on Monday\n\nDespite the two illnesses, World Triathlon and Paris 2024 have said in a Sunday statement that Monday's mixed relay triathlon will proceed as planned, saying that the water quality in the Seine has improved over the past few hours.\n\n\"The latest analysis results confirm that the water quality of the Seine at the triathlon site has improved over the past few hours, and prospective analyses indicate that the water quality will be within acceptable limits by World Triathlon. As a result, World Triathlon has made the decision this evening to continue the competition,\" the statement read in part.\n\nThe individual triathlon competitions went ahead on Wednesday after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier. More rain came into Paris overnight on Tuesday ahead of the race, but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3:30 a.m. attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. respectively,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a joint statement.\n\nThe athletes had largely put their trust in organizers to ensure that the water quality was safe for them. Women's silver medal winner Julie Derron of Switzerland said the athletes believed that the race was safe based on the word of authorities.\n\n\"The swimming was fine during the race. We know that they took samples this morning. They take a lot of time to analyze, so we don't know the results obviously. We all trust the authorities and the organizers that they keep us safe. And so we had a safe race today,\" she said.\n\nAfter the race, men's gold medal winner Alex Yee was complimentary to the organizers.\n\n\"We're lucky enough to have probably the most beautiful venue of any race in the Olympics. And I guess that came with a small penalty of the risk of the Seine being dirty,\" he said.\n\nHeavy rains battered Paris last weekend, drenching the opening ceremony and raising concerns about water quality in the river, which usually declines after rainfall.\n\nTraining was canceled for two straight days last week after water quality testing deemed the water unsafe for athletes, but organizers were confident at the time that the races would go ahead as planned.\n\nSeine clean-up\n\nThe decision to hold some swimming events in the famous river that splits Paris raised eyebrows when it was first announced. Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century but, in their desire to put the host city on full display, organizers worked up a plan to clean up the river so the world's best athletes could use it during Paris 2024.\n\nAbout $1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) had been spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games and Paris officials have made a big show of displaying its suitability. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier this month to display her confidence in the river's water quality and promised to put a swimming pool in the river after the Games. The French sports minister has also gone for a dip in the Seine.\n\nOne of the key infrastructure projects designed to help tackle pollution has been a new rainwater storage basin - called the Austerlitz basin - which can hold 20 Olympic swimming pools worth of water, according to a statement from Paris 2024.\n\nFollowing rainy weather on June 17 and 18, the basin filled to 80% capacity, successfully preventing 40,000 cubic meters (40 million liters) of wastewater and rainwater from being discharged into the Seine, according to the city of Paris.\n\nBut the water quality can change fast. Official data shows one-off rainfall events can quickly cause E. coli levels to spike again, and as recently as June 30 - following rain the previous day - E. coli levels increased to around 2000 CFU/100mL at Alexandra III Bridge, where the race is set to begin.\n\nThat's double the level needed for \"good\" water quality, as per World Triathlon standards.\n\nFor much of the month before the games, E. coli levels were above acceptable levels, which could expose athletes to serious health concerns. If E. Coli levels are above 1000 CFU/100mL, the swimming leg of the triathlon will have to be cancelled, according to World Triathlon competition rules, unless the organization's medical committee decides the race can go ahead.\n\nThe individual triathlon races took place with a 1.5-kilometer swim, followed by a 40K bike race - passing by the Le Grand Palais and the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es - before finishing with a 10K run through the heart of the city.\n\nThe mixed team relay race involving four athletes - two men and two women - will start with each team member completing a 300-meter swim, followed by a 5.8K bike ride and 1.8K run.\n\nCNN's Homero De La Fuente, Kevin Dotson and Chris Liakos contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All rights reserved.\n\nTHE-CNN-WIRE (TM) & \u00a9 2024 CABLE NEWS NETWORK, INC., A TIME WARNER COMPANY. {"uri": "2024-08-443876825", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:06:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:06:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:45:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.fox61.com/article/sports/olympics/mixed-relay-triathlon-team-withdraws-seine-water-quality/507-4d9ef0c9-8b88-419f-86ed-9843f20bb0a1", "title": "Mixed relay triathlon team withdraws after competitor who swam in the Seine falls ill", "body": "The mixed relay triathlon is scheduled to take place Monday, with the swim portion of the competition slated for the Seine as well.\n\nPARIS, France -- Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement.\n\nParis 2024 organizers had no immediate statement.\n\nThe mixed relay triathlon is scheduled to take place Monday, with the swim portion of the competition slated for the Seine as well. The statement did not elaborate on Michel's illness but it comes after concerns over the river's water quality. Organizers had said that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli, in the Seine's waters. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nWorld Triathlon's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection and the weather forecast when determining whether to go forward with a race. The decisions are made at early morning meetings on the day of the event.\n\nLeading up to the individual triathlon events, water quality concerns prompted organizers to cancel the swimming portion of two test runs meant to allow athletes to familiarize themselves with the course and also to delay the men's race by a day. Test swims in the Seine scheduled for Saturday and Sunday before the triathlon mixed relay were also canceled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nOrganizers have said that if the water quality is not acceptable for Monday's triathlon mixed relay, they can postpone it until Tuesday. If concerns persist, the plan is to skip the swimming leg and only have athletes compete in the biking and running portions.\n\nThe Belgian committee said it \"hopes that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games. We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, entourage and supporters.\"\n\nSwiss officials said Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who also competed in the Seine on Wednesday, fell ill with a stomach infection. But they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to the swim and that the other delegations told them none of their triathletes had reported stomach problems.\n\nSwiss officials said in an update Sunday that Simon Westermann, who had been tapped to replace Briffod, also had to withdraw because of a gastrointestinal infection. Westermann had not participated in any swims in the Seine, the statement said. The Swiss team still planned to compete in the mixed relay Monday.\n\nNorwegian triathlete Vetle Bergsvik Thorn got sick a day after competing in the men's triathlon. Thorn told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that he woke up the next day with an upset stomach and was vomiting but thought that the likely cause was food poisoning. He said he felt better later that day and was planning on competing again in the mixed relay scheduled for Monday.\n\nArild Tveiten, the sports director of the Norwegian Triathlon Federation, said the cause of Thorn's illness was unclear.\n\n\"We're thinking what everyone is thinking: that it's probably the river. But we don't know. It could be the river, it could be the chicken,\" Tveiten told NRK. \"The doctor is leaning toward the possibility of food poisoning. That's what the symptoms suggest.\"\n\nMarathon swimming events are set to be held in the Seine on Thursday and Friday.\n\nFive of the eight swimmers in the men's 1,500-meter freestyle Sunday night were listed to be entered in the 10-kilometer marathon swim.\n\nBronze medalist Daniel Wiffen of Ireland, who won an earlier gold in the 800 free, said he wouldn't train ahead of time in the Seine: \"I don't want to try to deal with any illness.\"\n\nHe said he would instead train in pools around Paris, even if it means \"going in blind.\"", "source": {"uri": "fox61.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8259103203", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:13:58", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:13:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:13:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/belgium-triathlon-athlete-falls-ill-after-swimming-in-seine-river_1008924.html?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter", "title": "Belgium Triathlon Athlete Falls Ill After Swimming in Seine River", "body": "PARIS -- Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement.\n\nParis 2024 organizers had no immediate statement on Michel's illness, but said in a statement Sunday night that the mixed relay triathlon would proceed Monday at 8 a.m. The swim portion of the competition is slated for the Seine, as well.\n\nThe Belgian committee's statement did not elaborate on Michel's illness but it comes after concerns over the river's water quality. Organizers had said that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nOn Sunday night, representatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities reviewed water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over recent hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli, in the Seine's waters. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nWorld Triathlon's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection, and the weather forecast when determining whether to go forward with a race. The decisions are made at early morning meetings on the day of the event.\n\nLeading up to the individual triathlon events, water quality concerns prompted organizers to cancel the swimming portion of two test runs meant to allow athletes to familiarize themselves with the course and also to delay the men's race by a day. Test swims in the Seine scheduled for Saturday and Sunday before the triathlon mixed relay were also canceled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nThe Belgian committee said it \"hopes that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games. We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, entourage and supporters.\"\n\nSwiss officials said Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who also competed in the Seine on Wednesday, fell ill with a stomach infection. But they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to the swim and that the other delegations told them none of their triathletes had reported stomach problems.\n\nSwiss officials said in an update Sunday that Simon Westermann, who had been tapped to replace Briffod, also had to withdraw because of a gastrointestinal infection. Westermann had not participated in any swims in the Seine, the statement said. The Swiss team still planned to compete in the mixed relay Monday.\n\nNorwegian triathlete Vetle Bergsvik Thorn got sick a day after competing in the men's triathlon. Thorn told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that he woke up the next day with an upset stomach and was vomiting but thought that the likely cause was food poisoning. He said he felt better later that day and was planning on competing again in the mixed relay scheduled for Monday.\n\nArild Tveiten, the sports director of the Norwegian Triathlon Federation, said the cause of Thorn's illness was unclear.\n\n\"We're thinking what everyone is thinking: that it's probably the river. But we don't know. It could be the river, it could be the chicken,\" Tveiten told NRK. \"The doctor is leaning toward the possibility of food poisoning. That's what the symptoms suggest.\"\n\nMarathon swimming events are set to be held in the Seine on Thursday and Friday.\n\nFive of the eight swimmers in the men's 1,500-meter freestyle Sunday night were listed to be entered in the 10-kilometer marathon swim.\n\nBronze medalist Daniel Wiffen of Ireland, who won an earlier gold in the 800 free, said he wouldn't train ahead of time in the Seine: {"uri": "2024-08-443911829", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:31:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:31:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:36:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/belgium-drops-out-of-mixed-triathlon-and-switzerland-shuffles-line-up-after-athletes-fall-ill-following-race-in-river-seine-1.6989132", "title": "Belgium drops out of mixed triathlon and Switzerland shuffles line-up after athletes fall ill following race in River Seine", "body": "Belgium has withdrawn from the mixed relay triathlon race on Monday and Switzerland has had to mix up its roster after athletes from both countries fell ill following the initial triathlon races last week.\n\nBelgium announced it was dropping out of the race after one of its triathletes, Claire Michel, has fallen ill, its National Olympic Committee said in a statement. The statement did not specify Michel's illness, which was reported days after she swam in the River Seine during the women's triathlon on Wednesday.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon must unfortunately announce that the 'Belgian Hammers' will not be starting the mixed relay at the Paris Olympic Games tomorrow. The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's triathlon competition on Wednesday.\n\nThe statement also had pointed words that appeared to be aimed at organizers: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games such as guaranteeing training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes and support personnel.\"\n\nThe Swiss team, meanwhile, had to replace Adrien Briffod, who had to withdraw due to a gastrointestinal infection. Simon Westermann will replace him.\n\nSwiss Olympic Chief Medical Officer Hanspeter Betschart noted that it is unclear if Briffod's infection is related to the Seine's water quality.\n\n\"A survey of my colleagues from other countries has so far not revealed any accumulation of gastrointestinal illnesses among the athletes who started the individual race last Wednesday,\" Betschart said.\n\nMixed relay triathlon to proceed on Monday\n\nDespite the two illnesses, World Triathlon and Paris 2024 have said in a Sunday statement that Monday's mixed relay triathlon will proceed as planned, saying that the water quality in the Seine has improved over the past few hours.\n\n\"The latest analysis results confirm that the water quality of the Seine at the triathlon site has improved over the past few hours, and prospective analyses indicate that the water quality will be within acceptable limits by World Triathlon. As a result, World Triathlon has made the decision this evening to continue the competition,\" the statement read in part.\n\nThe individual triathlon competitions went ahead on Wednesday after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier. More rain came into Paris overnight on Tuesday ahead of the race, but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3:30 a.m. attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. respectively,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a joint statement.\n\nThe athletes had largely put their trust in organizers to ensure that the water quality was safe for them. Women's silver medal winner Julie Derron of Switzerland said the athletes believed that the race was safe based on the word of authorities.\n\n\"The swimming was fine during the race. We know that they took samples this morning. They take a lot of time to analyze, so we don't know the results obviously. We all trust the authorities and the organizers that they keep us safe. And so we had a safe race today,\" she said.\n\nAfter the race, men's gold medal winner Alex Yee was complimentary to the organizers.\n\n\"We're lucky enough to have probably the most beautiful venue of any race in the Olympics. And I guess that came with a small penalty of the risk of the Seine being dirty,\" he said.\n\nHeavy rains battered Paris last weekend, drenching the opening ceremony and raising concerns about water quality in the river, which usually declines after rainfall.\n\nTraining was cancelled for two straight days last week after water quality testing deemed the water unsafe for athletes, but organizers were confident at the time that the races would go ahead as planned.\n\nSeine clean-up\n\nThe decision to hold some swimming events in the famous river that splits Paris raised eyebrows when it was first announced. Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century but, in their desire to put the host city on full display, organizers worked up a plan to clean up the river so the world's best athletes could use it during Paris 2024.\n\nAbout US$1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) had been spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games and Paris officials have made a big show of displaying its suitability. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier this month to display her confidence in the river's water quality and promised to put a swimming pool in the river after the Games. The French sports minister has also gone for a dip in the Seine.\n\nOne of the key infrastructure projects designed to help tackle pollution has been a new rainwater storage basin - called the Austerlitz basin - which can hold 20 Olympic swimming pools worth of water, according to a statement from Paris 2024.\n\nFollowing rainy weather on June 17 and 18, the basin filled to 80 per cent capacity, successfully preventing 40,000 cubic metres (40 million litres) of wastewater and rainwater from being discharged into the Seine, according to the city of Paris.\n\nBut the water quality can change fast. Official data shows one-off rainfall events can quickly cause E. coli levels to spike again, and as recently as June 30 - following rain the previous day - E. coli levels increased to around 2000 CFU/100mL at Alexandra III Bridge, where the race is set to begin.\n\nThat's double the level needed for \"good\" water quality, as per World Triathlon standards.\n\nFor much of the month before the games, E. coli levels were above acceptable levels, which could expose athletes to serious health concerns. If E. Coli levels are above 1000 CFU/100mL, the swimming leg of the triathlon will have to be cancelled, according to World Triathlon competition rules, unless the organization's medical committee decides the race can go ahead.\n\nThe individual triathlon races took place with a 1.5-kilometer swim, followed by a 40K bike race - passing by the Le Grand Palais and the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es - before finishing with a 10K run through the heart of the city.\n\nThe mixed team relay race involving four athletes - two men and two women - will start with each team member completing a 300-metre swim, followed by a 5.8K bike ride and 1.8K run.\n\nCNN's Homero De La Fuente, Kevin Dotson and Chris Liakos contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV Summer Olympics \u2013 Mixed relay"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Triathlon", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "World Triathlon"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443771675", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:33:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:33:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:19:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/08/04/sport/belgium-withdraws-mixed-relay-triathlon-seine-spt/index.html", "title": "Belgium withdraws from mixed relay triathlon after triathlete falls ill days after swimming in the Seine", "body": "Athletes dive into the River Seine to start the swimming stage of the men's individual triathlon at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games on July 31.\n\nBelgium has withdrawn from the mixed relay triathlon race on Monday after one of its triathletes, Claire Michel, has fallen ill, its National Olympic Committee said in a statement.\n\nThe statement did not specify Michel's illness, which was reported days after she swam in the River Seine during the women's triathlon on Wednesday.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon must unfortunately announce that the 'Belgian Hammers' will not be starting the mixed relay at the Paris Olympic Games tomorrow. The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's triathlon competition on Wednesday.\n\nBelgian triathlete Claire Michel finished 38th in the women's individual triathlon.\n\nJasper Jacobs/AFP/Getty Images\n\nThe statement also had pointed words that appeared to be aimed at organizers: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games such as guaranteeing training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes and support personnel.\"\n\nTriathlons proceeded amid water quality concerns\n\nThe triathlon competitions went ahead in Paris after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier. More rain came into Paris overnight ahead of the race, but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3:30 a.m. attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. respectively,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a joint statement.\n\nThe athletes had largely put their trust in organizers to ensure that the water quality was safe for them. Women's silver medal winner Julie Derron of Switzerland said the athletes believed that the race was safe based on the word of authorities.\n\n\"The swimming was fine during the race. We know that they took samples this morning. They take a lot of time to analyze, so we don't know the results obviously. We all trust the authorities and the organizers that they keep us safe. And so we had a safe race today,\" she said.\n\nAfter the race, men's gold medal winner Alex Yee was complimentary to the organizers.\n\n\"We're lucky enough to have probably the most beautiful venue of any race in the Olympics. And I guess that came with a small penalty of the risk of the Seine being dirty,\" he said.\n\nHeavy rains battered Paris last weekend, drenching the opening ceremony and raising concerns about water quality in the river, which usually declines after rainfall.\n\nTraining was canceled for two straight days last week after water quality testing deemed the water unsafe for athletes, but organizers were confident at the time that the races would go ahead as planned.\n\nSeine clean-up\n\nThe decision to hold some swimming events in the famous river that splits Paris raised eyebrows when it was first announced. Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century but, in their desire to put the host city on full display, organizers worked up a plan to clean up the river so the world's best athletes could use it during Paris 2024.\n\nAbout $1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) had been spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games and Paris officials have made a big show of displaying its suitability. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier this month to display her confidence in the river's water quality and promised to put a swimming pool in the river after the Games. The French sports minister has also gone for a dip in the Seine.\n\nVideo Ad Feedback\n\nCNN reporter goes swimming in the Seine after $1.5B cleanup. See how it went\n\n01:23 - Source: CNN\n\nOne of the key infrastructure projects designed to help tackle pollution has been a new rainwater storage basin - called the Austerlitz basin - which can hold 20 Olympic swimming pools worth of water, according to a statement from Paris 2024.\n\nFollowing rainy weather on June 17 and 18, the basin filled to 80% capacity, successfully preventing 40,000 cubic meters (40 million liters) of wastewater and rainwater from being discharged into the Seine, according to the city of Paris.\n\nBut the water quality can change fast. Official data shows one-off rainfall events can quickly cause E. coli levels to spike again, and as recently as June 30 - following rain the previous day - E. coli levels increased to around 2000 CFU/100mL at Alexandra III Bridge, where the race is set to begin.\n\nThat's double the level needed for \"good\" water quality, as per World Triathlon standards.\n\nFor much of the month before the games, E. coli levels were above acceptable levels, which could expose athletes to serious health concerns. If E. Coli levels are above 1000 CFU/100mL, the swimming leg of the triathlon will have to be cancelled, according to World Triathlon competition rules, unless the organization's medical committee decides the race can go ahead.\n\nThe individual triathlon races took place with a 1.5-kilometer swim, followed by a 40K bike race - passing by the Le Grand Palais and the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es - before finishing with a 10K run through the heart of the city.\n\nThe mixed team relay race involving four athletes - two men and two women - will start with each team member completing a 300-meter swim, followed by a 5.8K bike ride and 1.8K run.\n\nCNN's Homero De La Fuente, Kevin Dotson and Chris Liakos contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, {"uri": "8259272427", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:32:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:32:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:30:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://gorgenewscenter.com/2024/08/04/belgium-withdraws-from-mixed-relay-triathlon-after-athlete-who-swam-in-seine-river-falls-ill/", "title": "Belgium withdraws from mixed relay triathlon after athlete who swam in Seine River falls ill", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement.\n\nParis 2024 organizers had no immediate statement on Michel's illness, but said in a statement Sunday night that the mixed relay triathlon would proceed Monday at 8 a.m. The swim portion of the competition is slated for the Seine.\n\nThe Belgian committee's statement did not elaborate on Michel's illness but it comes after concerns over the river's water quality. Organizers had said that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nOn Sunday night, representatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities reviewed water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over recent hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli, in the Seine's waters. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nWorld Triathlon's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection and the weather forecast when determining whether to go forward with a race. The decisions have generally been made at early morning meetings on the day of the event. But in announcing Sunday night that the race would happen Monday, organizers said they were responding to requests from athletes to give them more time to prepare.\n\nLeading up to the individual triathlon events, water quality concerns prompted organizers to cancel the swimming portion of two test runs meant to allow athletes to familiarize themselves with the course and also to delay the men's race by a day. Test swims in the Seine scheduled for Saturday and Sunday before the triathlon mixed relay were also canceled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nThe Belgian committee said it \"hopes that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games. We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, entourage and supporters.\"\n\nSwiss officials said Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who also competed in the Seine on Wednesday, fell ill with a stomach infection. But they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to the swim and that the other delegations told them none of their triathletes had reported stomach problems.\n\nSwiss officials said in an update Sunday that Simon Westermann, who had been tapped to replace Briffod, also had to withdraw because of a gastrointestinal infection. Westermann had not participated in any swims in the Seine, the statement said. The Swiss team still planned to compete in the mixed relay Monday.\n\nNorwegian triathlete Vetle Bergsvik Thorn got sick a day after competing in the men's triathlon. Thorn told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that he woke up the next day with an upset stomach and was vomiting but thought that the likely cause was food poisoning. He said he felt better later that day and was planning on competing again in the mixed relay scheduled for Monday.\n\nArild Tveiten, the sports director of the Norwegian Triathlon Federation, said the cause of Thorn's illness was unclear.\n\n\"We're thinking what everyone is thinking: that it's probably the river. But we don't know. It could be the river, it could be the chicken,\" Tveiten told NRK. \"The doctor is leaning toward the possibility of food poisoning. That's what the symptoms suggest.\"\n\nMarathon swimming events are set to be held in the Seine on Thursday and Friday.\n\nFive of the eight swimmers in the men's 1,500-meter freestyle Sunday night were listed to be entered in the 10-kilometer marathon swim.\n\nBronze medalist Daniel Wiffen of Ireland, who won an earlier gold in the 800 free, said he wouldn't train ahead of time in the Seine: \"I don't want to try to deal with any illness.\"\n\nHe said he would instead train in pools around Paris, even if it means \"going in blind.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists Karl Ritter and Janie McCauley contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "gorgenewscenter.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "gorgenewscenter.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259063620", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:21:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:21:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:19:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "http://thepeninsulaqatar.com/article/04/08/2024/belgium-withdraws-from-mixed-relay-triathlon-after-athlete-who-swam-in-seine-falls-ill", "title": "Belgium withdraws from mixed relay triathlon after athlete who swam in Seine falls ill", "body": "Paris: Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement. Paris 2024 organizers had no immediate statement.\n\nThe mixed relay triathlon is scheduled to take place Monday, with the swim portion of the competition slated for the Seine as well. The statement did not elaborate on Michel's illness but it comes after concerns over the river's water quality. Organizers had said that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli, in the Seine's waters. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nWorld Triathlon's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection and the weather forecast when determining whether to go forward with a race. The decisions are made at early morning meetings on the day of the event.\n\nLeading up to the individual triathlon events, water quality concerns prompted organizers to cancel the swimming portion of two test runs meant to allow athletes to familiarize themselves with the course and also to delay the men's race by a day.\n\nTest swims in the Seine scheduled for Saturday and Sunday before the triathlon mixed relay were also canceled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nOrganizers have said that if the water quality is not acceptable for Monday's triathlon mixed relay, they can postpone it until Tuesday. If concerns persist, the plan is to skip the swimming leg and only have athletes compete in the biking and running portions.\n\nThe Belgian committee said it \"hopes that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games. We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, entourage and supporters.\"\n\nSwiss officials said Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who also competed in the Seine on Wednesday, fell ill with a stomach infection. But they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to the swim and that the other delegations told them none of their triathletes had reported stomach problems.\n\nSwiss officials said in an update Sunday that Simon Westermann, who had been tapped to replace Briffod, also had to withdraw because of a gastrointestinal infection.\n\nWestermann had not participated in any swims in the Seine, the statement said. The Swiss team still planned to compete in the mixed relay Monday.\n\nNorwegian triathlete Vetle Bergsvik Thorn got sick a day after competing in the men's triathlon. Thorn told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that he woke up the next day with an upset stomach and was vomiting but thought that the likely cause was food poisoning.\n\nHe said he felt better later that day and was planning on competing again in the mixed relay scheduled for Monday.\n\nArild Tveiten, the sports director of the Norwegian Triathlon Federation, said the cause of Thorn's illness was unclear.\n\n\"We're thinking what everyone is thinking: that it's probably the river. But we don't know. It could be the river, it could be the chicken,\" Tveiten told NRK. \"The doctor is leaning toward the possibility of food poisoning. That's what the symptoms suggest.\"\n\nMarathon swimming events are set to be held in the Seine on Thursday and Friday.\n\nFive of the eight swimmers in the men's 1,500-meter freestyle Sunday night were listed to be entered in the 10-kilometer marathon swim.\n\nBronze medalist Daniel Wiffen of Ireland, who won an earlier gold in the 800 free, said he wouldn't train ahead of time in the Seine: \"I don't want to try to deal with any illness.\"\n\nHe said he would instead train in pools around Paris, even if it means \"going in blind.\"", "source": {"uri": "thepeninsulaqatar.com", "dataType": "http://thepeninsulaqatar.com/get/maximage/20240804_1722802535-541.jpeg?1722802535", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9788308", "eventUri": "eng-9788308", "location": {"type": "country", {"uri": "8259273697", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:33:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:33:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:32:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.fox41yakima.com/belgium-withdraws-from-mixed-relay-triathlon-after-athlete-who-swam-in-seine-river-falls-ill/", "title": "Belgium withdraws from mixed relay triathlon after athlete who swam in Seine River falls ill | Fox 11 Tri Cities Fox 41 Yakima", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement.\n\nParis 2024 organizers had no immediate statement on Michel's illness, but said in a statement Sunday night that the mixed relay triathlon would proceed Monday at 8 a.m. The swim portion of the competition is slated for the Seine.\n\nThe Belgian committee's statement did not elaborate on Michel's illness but it comes after concerns over the river's water quality. Organizers had said that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nOn Sunday night, representatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities reviewed water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over recent hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli, in the Seine's waters. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nWorld Triathlon's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection and the weather forecast when determining whether to go forward with a race. The decisions have generally been made at early morning meetings on the day of the event. But in announcing Sunday night that the race would happen Monday, organizers said they were responding to requests from athletes to give them more time to prepare.\n\nLeading up to the individual triathlon events, water quality concerns prompted organizers to cancel the swimming portion of two test runs meant to allow athletes to familiarize themselves with the course and also to delay the men's race by a day. Test swims in the Seine scheduled for Saturday and Sunday before the triathlon mixed relay were also canceled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nThe Belgian committee said it \"hopes that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games. We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, entourage and supporters.\"\n\nSwiss officials said Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who also competed in the Seine on Wednesday, fell ill with a stomach infection. But they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to the swim and that the other delegations told them none of their triathletes had reported stomach problems.\n\nSwiss officials said in an update Sunday that Simon Westermann, who had been tapped to replace Briffod, also had to withdraw because of a gastrointestinal infection. Westermann had not participated in any swims in the Seine, the statement said. The Swiss team still planned to compete in the mixed relay Monday.\n\nNorwegian triathlete Vetle Bergsvik Thorn got sick a day after competing in the men's triathlon. Thorn told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that he woke up the next day with an upset stomach and was vomiting but thought that the likely cause was food poisoning. He said he felt better later that day and was planning on competing again in the mixed relay scheduled for Monday.\n\nArild Tveiten, the sports director of the Norwegian Triathlon Federation, said the cause of Thorn's illness was unclear.\n\n\"We're thinking what everyone is thinking: that it's probably the river. But we don't know. It could be the river, it could be the chicken,\" Tveiten told NRK. \"The doctor is leaning toward the possibility of food poisoning. That's what the symptoms suggest.\"\n\nMarathon swimming events are set to be held in the Seine on Thursday and Friday.\n\nFive of the eight swimmers in the men's 1,500-meter freestyle Sunday night were listed to be entered in the 10-kilometer marathon swim.\n\nBronze medalist Daniel Wiffen of Ireland, who won an earlier gold in the 800 free, said he wouldn't train ahead of time in the Seine: \"I don't want to try to deal with any illness.\"\n\nHe said he would instead train in pools around Paris, even if it means \"going in blind.\"\n\nAssociated Press journalists Karl Ritter and Janie McCauley contributed reporting.\n\nFor more coverage of the Paris Olympics, visit https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games.\n\nFOX41 Yakima\u00a9FOX11 TriCities\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox41yakima.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 11 41 Tri Cities Yakima"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@fox41yakima.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": "https://www.fox41yakima.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/66a9e4bf694f3image_.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9788308", "eventUri": "eng-9788308", "location": {"type": "country", {"uri": "8259298671", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:08:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:08:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:07:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/belgiums-triathlon-team-pulls-out-of-olympic-mixed-relay-event-after-athlete-who-swam-in-seine-falls-ill-13191083", "title": "Belgium's triathlon team pulls out of Olympic mixed relay event after athlete who swam in Seine falls ill", "body": "Claire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon last week, fell ill on Sunday but the Belgian Olympic committee has not elaborated on her condition. It comes after concerns over water quality in the Seine, where the swimming portion of triathlons is taking place.\n\nBelgium has pulled out of the Olympic mixed relay triathlon after an athlete who swam in the River Seine fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said on Sunday.\n\nMichel, 35, was taken to a clinic in the Olympic Village and stayed in the athletes' accommodation area on Sunday night.\n\nBelgian officials did not elaborate on Michel's illness but the team's withdrawal comes after questions about the water quality of the Seine. Michel competed in the women's triathlon on Wednesday, finishing 38th.\n\nIn the run-up to the individual triathlon events last week, concerns prompted organisers to delay the men's race by a day and cancel the swimming portion of two test runs.\n\nTest swims scheduled for Saturday and Sunday were also cancelled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nBut organisers confirmed on Sunday night that the mixed relay triathlon would proceed at 8am on Monday after water tests were reviewed.\n\nThey added that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of faecal bacteria, including E. coli, in the Seine's waters.\n\nWorld Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels of up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 millilitres can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nThe organisation's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection and the weather forecast when determining whether to go forward with a race.\n\nBelgium's Olympic team released a statement saying reports Michel was in hospital for four days were incorrect.\n\nThe team also said that it \"hopes that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games\".\n\nIt added: \"We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, entourage and supporters.\"\n\nOrganisers of the Paris 2024 Games said they wished Ms Michel \"a quick recovery and will seek regular updates on their health\".\n\nThey added: \"Paris 2024 wishes to remind everyone that the health and wellbeing of athletes is our top priority.\n\n\"With respect to competitions held in the Seine, water quality tests are carried out daily and the decision on whether to proceed with an event is taken by the International Federation, World Triathlon, in coordination with Paris 2024, and based on the results and a range of criteria.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Swiss officials said on Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who also competed in the Seine on Wednesday, fell ill with a stomach infection.\n\nBut they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to the swim and that the other delegations told them none of their triathletes had reported stomach problems.\n\nSimon Westermann, who had been lined up to replace Briffod, also had to withdraw because of a gastrointestinal infection, Swiss officials said in an update on Sunday.\n\nWestermann had not participated in any swims in the Seine, the statement said.\n\nNorwegian triathlete Vetle Bergsvik Thorn also got sick a day after competing in the men's triathlon.\n\nThorn told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that he woke up the next day with an upset stomach and was vomiting but thought that the likely cause was food poisoning.\n\nHe said he felt better later that day and was planning on competing again in the {"uri": "8259044672", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:56:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:56:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:55:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.adn.com/sports/national-sports/2024/08/04/belgium-withdraws-from-mixed-relay-triathlon-after-athlete-who-swam-in-seine-river-falls-ill/", "title": "Belgium withdraws from mixed relay triathlon after athlete who swam in Seine River falls ill", "body": "PARIS -- Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement.\n\nParis 2024 organizers had no immediate statement.\n\nThe mixed relay triathlon is scheduled to take place Monday, with the swim portion of the competition slated for the Seine as well. The statement did not elaborate on Michel's illness but it comes after concerns over the river's water quality. Organizers had said that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli, in the Seine's waters. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nWorld Triathlon's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection and the weather forecast when determining whether to go forward with a race. The decisions are made at early morning meetings on the day of the event.\n\nLeading up to the individual triathlon events, water quality concerns prompted organizers to cancel the swimming portion of two test runs meant to allow athletes to familiarize themselves with the course and also to delay the men's race by a day. Test swims in the Seine scheduled for Saturday and Sunday before the triathlon mixed relay were also canceled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nOrganizers have said that if the water quality is not acceptable for Monday's triathlon mixed relay, they can postpone it until Tuesday. If concerns persist, the plan is to skip the swimming leg and only have athletes compete in the biking and running portions.\n\nThe Belgian committee said it \"hopes that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games. We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, entourage and supporters.\"\n\nSwiss officials said Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who also competed in the Seine on Wednesday, fell ill with a stomach infection. But they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to the swim and that the other delegations told them none of their triathletes had reported stomach problems.\n\nSwiss officials said in an update Sunday that Simon Westermann, who had been tapped to replace Briffod, also had to withdraw because of a gastrointestinal infection. Westermann had not participated in any swims in the Seine, the statement said. The Swiss team still planned to compete in the mixed relay Monday.\n\nNorwegian triathlete Vetle Bergsvik Thorn got sick a day after competing in the men's triathlon. Thorn told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that he woke up the next day with an upset stomach and was vomiting but thought that the likely cause was food poisoning. He said he felt better later that day and was planning on competing again in the mixed relay scheduled for Monday.\n\nArild Tveiten, the sports director of the Norwegian Triathlon Federation, said the cause of Thorn's illness was unclear.\n\n\"We're thinking what everyone is thinking: that it's probably the river. But we don't know. It could be the river, it could be the chicken,\" Tveiten told NRK. \"The doctor is leaning toward the possibility of food poisoning. That's what the symptoms suggest.\"\n\nMarathon swimming events are set to be held in the Seine on Thursday and Friday.\n\nFive of the eight swimmers in the men's 1,500-meter freestyle Sunday night were listed to be entered in the 10-kilometer marathon swim.\n\nBronze medalist Daniel Wiffen of Ireland, who won an earlier gold in the 800 free, said he wouldn't train ahead of time in the Seine: \"I don't want to try to deal with any illness.\"\n\nHe said he would instead train in pools around Paris, even if it means \"going in blind.\"\n\nAssociated Press journalists Karl Ritter and Janie McCauley contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "adn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Anchorage Daily News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443921942", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:04:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:04:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:03:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.chelmsfordweeklynews.co.uk/sport/national/24496940.mixed-relay-go-ahead-despite-withdrawal-belgium-due-e-coli-illness/", "title": "Mixed relay to go ahead despite withdrawal of Belgium due to 'E. coli' illness", "body": "The Olympic triathlon mixed relay will go ahead on Monday in Paris but without Belgium, who have withdrawn citing an illness for athlete Claire Michel amid reports it is a case of E. coli.\n\nThe health of athletes competing in the triathlon events at these Games has been a hot topic following concerns over the water quality of the River Seine.\n\nOlympic organisers cancelled the swim familiarisation sessions over the weekend as the water quality levels had dropped back below the required standards following heavy rain.\n\nBut on Sunday evening it was announced the mixed relay would take place as scheduled on Monday morning.\n\n\"The latest test results confirm that Seine water quality levels at the triathlon venue have improved in recent hours, with forward-looking analysis indicating that water quality will be within the levels acceptable by World Triathlon,\" read a statement.\n\nThe men's triathlon was postponed by one day earlier in the week to Wednesday and took place on the same day as the women's event.\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's race on Wednesday.\n\nA joint statement from the Belgian Olympic Committee (COIB) and Belgium Triathlon announced their withdrawal from the mixed relay.\n\nIt said: \"The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and the entourage.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and has to withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nBelgian media reported that Michel has contracted E. coli.\n\nThe team statement did not confirm that, but notably added: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for the next triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games.\n\nGames organisers did not confirm or deny the E. coli reports, but did state that the 35-year-old has not been hospitalised.\n\n\"We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the format of the competitions which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, the entourage and the supporters.\"\n\n\"Paris 2024 wishes the athlete involved a quick recovery and will seek regular updates on their health,\" a spokesperson said. \"Paris 2024 wishes to remind everyone that the health and well-being of athletes is our top priority.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Switzerland have made a change to their line-up after Adrien Briffod also fell ill, with Simon Westermann taking his place.\n\n\"I don't really know if my condition is linked to the quality of the water in the Seine,\" Briffod told Le Matin.\n\nHeavy rain hit Paris on Wednesday and Thursday, causing levels of bacteria in the water to rise.\n\nPrior to the men's and women's events taking place on Wednesday, athletes had been unable to train in the river because the water quality had not passed the required tests.\n\nBritain's athletes are all understood to have avoided any ill effects from swimming in the water, but all nations have faced disruption to their preparations.\n\nBritain won gold in the inaugural Olympic mixed relay in Tokyo and will be among the favourites to secure another medal.\n\nIn Wednesday's triathlons, Great Britain's Alex Yee won a gold medal in the men's race and Beth Potter won bronze in the women's competition.\n\nYee and Potter will compete along with
