despite withdrawal of Belgium due to 'E. coli' illness", "body": "There have been concerns over the water quality in the River Seine.\n\nThe Olympic triathlon mixed relay will go ahead on Monday in Games has been a hot topic following concerns over the water quality of the River Seine.\n\nOlympic organisers cancelled the swim familiarisation sessions over the weekend as the water quality levels had dropped back below the required standards following heavy rain.\n\nBut on Sunday evening it was announced the mixed relay would take place as scheduled on Monday morning.\n\n\"The latest test by World Triathlon,\" read a statement.\n\nThe men's triathlon was postponed by one day earlier in the week to Wednesday and took place on the same day as the women's event.\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's race on Wednesday.\n\nIt said: \"The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and the entourage.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and has to withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nBelgian media reported that Michel has contracted E. coli.\n\nThe team statement did not confirm that, but notably added: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for the next triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games.\n\nGames organisers did not confirm or deny the E. coli reports, but did state that the 35-year-old has not been hospitalised.\n\n\"We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the format of the competitions which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, the entourage and the supporters.\"\n\n\"Paris 2024 wishes the athlete involved a quick recovery and will seek regular updates on their health,\" a spokesperson said. \"Paris 2024 wishes to remind everyone that the health and well-being of athletes is our top priority.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Switzerland have made a change to their line-up after Adrien Briffod also fell ill, with Simon Westermann taking his place.\n\n\"I don't really know if my condition is linked to the quality of the water in the Seine,\" Briffod told Le Matin.\n\nHeavy rain hit Paris on Wednesday and Thursday, causing levels of bacteria in the water to rise.\n\nBritain's athletes are all understood to have avoided any ill effects from swimming in the water, but all nations have faced disruption to their preparations.\n\nBritain won gold in the inaugural Olympic mixed relay in Tokyo and will be among the favourites to secure another medal.\n\nIn Wednesday's triathlons, Great Britain's Alex Yee won a gold medal in the men's race and Beth Potter won bronze in the women's competition.\n\nYee and Potter will compete along with Georgia Taylor-Brown and Sam Dickinson.", Seine.\n\nOlympic organisers cancelled the swim familiarisation sessions over the weekend as the water quality levels had dropped back below the required standards following heavy rain.\n\nBut on Sunday evening it was announced the mixed relay would take place as scheduled on Monday morning.\n\n\"The latest test results confirm that Seine water quality levels at the triathlon venue have improved in recent hours, with forward-looking analysis indicating that water quality will be within the levels acceptable by World Triathlon,\" read a statement.\n\nThe men's triathlon was postponed by one day earlier in the week to Wednesday and took place on the same day as the women's event.\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's race on Wednesday.\n\nBelgium\u00b4s Claire Michel, far right, "https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2024/08/04/23/wire-88152717-1722811360-523_636x382.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9788308", "eventUri": "eng-9788308", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1294117647058823, "wgt": 200, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8259159121", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:34:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:34:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:33:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://kion546.com/sports/cnn-sports/2024/08/04/belgium-drops-out-of-mixed-triathlon-and-switzerland-shuffles-line-up-after-athletes-fall-ill-following-race-in-river-seine/", "title": "Belgium drops out of mixed triathlon and Switzerland shuffles line-up after athletes fall ill following race in River Seine - KION546", "body": "Paris (CNN) -- Belgium has withdrawn from the mixed relay triathlon race on Monday and Switzerland has had to mix up its roster after athletes from both countries fell ill following the initial triathlon races last week.\n\nBelgium announced it was dropping out of the race after one of its triathletes, Claire Michel, has fallen ill, its National Olympic Committee said in a statement. The statement did not specify Michel's illness, which was reported days after she swam in the River Seine during the women's triathlon on Wednesday.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon must unfortunately announce that the 'Belgian Hammers' will not be starting the mixed relay at the Paris Olympic Games tomorrow. The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's triathlon competition on Wednesday.\n\nThe statement also had pointed words that appeared to be aimed at organizers: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games such as guaranteeing training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes and support personnel.\"\n\nThe Swiss team, meanwhile, had to replace Adrien Briffod, who had to withdraw due to a gastrointestinal infection. Simon Westermann will replace him.\n\nSwiss Olympic Chief Medical Officer Hanspeter Betschart noted that it is unclear if Briffod's infection is related to the Seine's water quality.\n\n\"A survey of my colleagues from other countries has so far not revealed any accumulation of gastrointestinal illnesses among the athletes who started the individual race last Wednesday,\" Betschart said.\n\nThe Paris 2024 organizers of the Games said in a statement that the water quality in the Seine was at a \"very good\" level on the morning of the individual triathlons.\n\n\"Paris 2024 wishes to remind everyone that the health and wellbeing of athletes is our top priority. With respect to competitions held in the Seine, water quality tests are carried out daily, and the decision on whether to proceed with an event is taken by the International Federation World Triathlon, in coordination with Paris 2024, and based on the results and a range of (notably health) criteria,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Water samples taken in the Seine on the morning of the individual triathlon events showed the quality to be at a level considered 'very good' by World Triathlon's criteria, according to results analysed and released the following day,\" the statement added in part.\n\nDespite the two illnesses, World Triathlon and Paris 2024 have said in a Sunday statement that Monday's mixed relay triathlon will proceed as planned, saying that the water quality in the Seine has improved over the past few hours.\n\n\"The latest analysis results confirm that the water quality of the Seine at the triathlon site has improved over the past few hours, and prospective analyses indicate that the water quality will be within acceptable limits by World Triathlon. As a result, World Triathlon has made the decision this evening to continue the competition,\" the statement read in part.\n\nThe individual triathlon competitions went ahead on Wednesday after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier. More rain came into Paris overnight on Tuesday ahead of the race, but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3:30 a.m. attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. respectively,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a joint statement.\n\nThe athletes had largely put their trust in organizers to ensure that the water quality was safe for them. Women's silver medal winner Julie Derron of Switzerland said the athletes believed that the race was safe based on the word of authorities.\n\n\"The swimming was fine during the race. We know that they took samples this morning. They take a lot of time to analyze, so we don't know the results obviously. We all trust the authorities and the organizers that they keep us safe. And so we had a safe race today,\" she said.\n\nAfter the race, men's gold medal winner Alex Yee was complimentary to the organizers.\n\n\"We're lucky enough to have probably the most beautiful venue of any race in the Olympics. And I guess that came with a small penalty of the risk of the Seine being dirty,\" he said.\n\nHeavy rains battered Paris last weekend, drenching the opening ceremony and raising concerns about water quality in the river, which usually declines after rainfall.\n\nTraining was canceled for two straight days last week after water quality testing deemed the water unsafe for athletes, but organizers were confident at the time that the races would go ahead as planned.\n\nThe decision to hold some swimming events in the famous river that splits Paris raised eyebrows when it was first announced. Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century but, in their desire to put the host city on full display, organizers worked up a plan to clean up the river so the world's best athletes could use it during Paris 2024.\n\nAbout $1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) had been spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games and Paris officials have made a big show of displaying its suitability. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier this month to display her confidence in the river's water quality and promised to put a swimming pool in the river after the Games. The French sports minister has also gone for a dip in the Seine.\n\nOne of the key infrastructure projects designed to help tackle pollution has been a new rainwater storage basin - called the Austerlitz basin - which can hold 20 Olympic swimming pools worth of water, according to a statement from Paris 2024.\n\nFollowing rainy weather on June 17 and 18, the basin filled to 80% capacity, successfully preventing 40,000 cubic meters (40 million liters) of wastewater and rainwater from being discharged into the Seine, according to the city of Paris.\n\nBut the water quality can change fast. Official data shows one-off rainfall events can quickly cause E. coli levels to spike again, and as recently as June 30 - following rain the previous day - E. coli levels increased to around 2000 CFU/100mL at Alexandra III Bridge, where the race is set to begin.\n\nThat's double the level needed for \"good\" water quality, as per World Triathlon standards.\n\nFor much of the month before the games, E. coli levels were above acceptable levels, which could expose athletes to serious health concerns. If E. Coli levels are above 1000 CFU/100mL, the swimming leg of the triathlon will have to be cancelled, according to World Triathlon competition rules, unless the organization's medical committee decides the race can go ahead.\n\nThe individual triathlon races took place with a 1.5-kilometer swim, followed by a 40K bike race - passing by the Le Grand Palais and the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es - before finishing with a 10K run through the heart of the city.\n\nThe mixed team relay race involving four athletes - two men and two women - will start with each team member completing a 300-meter swim, followed by a 5.8K bike ride and 1.8K run.\n\nCNN's Homero De La Fuente, Kevin Dotson and Chris Liakos contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8259202244", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:42:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:42:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:41:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/olympics/article-13708437/Olympic-mixed-triathlon-ahead-amid-ongoing-concerns-water-quality-Belgium-pulling-one-athlete-falling-ill-swimming-River-Seine.html", "title": "Olympic mixed triathlon WILL go ahead amid concerns over water quality", "body": "Belgium's Claire Michel is currently in hospital with a reported E.coli infection\n\nThe Olympic triathlon mixed relay will go ahead on Monday in Paris but without Belgium, who have withdrawn citing an illness for athlete Claire Michel amid reports it is a case of E. coli.\n\nThe health of athletes competing in the triathlon events at these Games has been a hot topic following concerns over the water quality of the River Seine.\n\nOlympic organisers cancelled the swim familiarisation sessions over the weekend as the water quality levels had dropped back below the required standards following heavy rain.\n\nBut on Sunday evening it was announced the mixed relay would take place as scheduled on Monday morning.\n\nA statement read: 'Following requests from the triathlon teams to provide the athletes with more time to prepare for the upcoming Mixed Relay competition, a meeting took place today August 4th at 19:00 to review the water quality results, with representatives from World Triathlon, Paris 2024, the International Olympic Committee, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, DRIEAT, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests. During this meeting, World Triathlon took the decision to move ahead with the Mixed Relay competition, scheduled for Monday, August 5, at 8am.\n\nThe Olympic triathlon mixed relay will go ahead on Monday in Paris but without Belgium\n\nBelgium's Claire Michel is currently in hospital amid reports it is an E.coli infection\n\n'The latest test results confirm that Seine water quality levels at the triathlon venue have improved in recent hours, with forward looking analysis indicating that water quality will be within the levels acceptable by World Triathlon. As a result, World Triathlon has taken the decision this evening to go ahead with the competition.'\n\nThe men's triathlon was postponed by one day earlier in the week to Wednesday and took place on the same day as the women's event.\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's race on Wednesday.\n\nA joint statement from the Belgian Olympic Committee (COIB) and Belgium Triathlon announced their withdrawal from the mixed relay.\n\nIt said: 'The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and the entourage.\n\n'Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and has to withdraw from the competition.'\n\nBelgian media reported that Michel has contracted E. coli.\n\nThe team statement did not confirm that, but notably added: 'The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for the next triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games.\n\nWorld Triathlon stated that tests showed the quality of the water in the Seine has improved\n\nSwitzerland had to make a change to their line-up after Adrien Briffod also fell ill\n\nGames organisers did not confirm or deny the E. coli reports, but did state that the 35-year-old has not been hospitalised.\n\n'We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the format of the competitions which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, the entourage and the supporters.'\n\n'Paris 2024 wishes the athlete involved a quick recovery and will seek regular updates on their health,' a spokesperson said. 'Paris 2024 wishes to remind everyone that the health and well-being of athletes is our top priority.'\n\nMeanwhile, Switzerland have made a change to their line-up after Adrien Briffod also fell ill, with Simon Westermann taking his place.\n\n'I don't really know if my condition is linked to the quality of the water in the Seine,' Briffod told Le Matin.\n\nHeavy rain hit Paris on Wednesday and Thursday, causing levels of bacteria in the water to rise.\n\nPrior to the men's and women's events taking place on Wednesday, athletes had been unable to train in the river because the water quality had not passed the required tests.\n\nBritain's athletes are all understood to have avoided any ill effects from swimming in the water, but all nations have faced disruption to their preparations.\n\nBritain won gold in the inaugural Olympic mixed relay in Tokyo and will be among the favourites to secure another medal.\n\nIn Wednesday's triathlons, Great Britain's Alex Yee won a gold medal in the men's race and Beth Potter won bronze in the women's competition.\n\nYee and Potter will compete along with Georgia Taylor-Brown and Sam Dickinson.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8259151361", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:21:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:21:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:20:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://keyt.com/sports/national-sports/cnn-sports/2024/08/04/belgium-drops-out-of-mixed-triathlon-and-switzerland-shuffles-line-up-after-athletes-fall-ill-following-race-in-river-seine/", "title": "Belgium drops out of mixed triathlon and Switzerland shuffles line-up after athletes fall ill following race in River Seine", "body": "Paris (CNN) -- Belgium has withdrawn from the mixed relay triathlon race on Monday and Switzerland has had to mix up its roster after athletes from both countries fell ill following the initial triathlon races last week.\n\nBelgium announced it was dropping out of the race after one of its triathletes, Claire Michel, has fallen ill, its National Olympic Committee said in a statement. The statement did not specify Michel's illness, which was reported days after she swam in the River Seine during the women's triathlon on Wednesday.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon must unfortunately announce that the 'Belgian Hammers' will not be starting the mixed relay at the Paris Olympic Games tomorrow. The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's triathlon competition on Wednesday.\n\nThe statement also had pointed words that appeared to be aimed at organizers: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games such as guaranteeing training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes and support personnel.\"\n\nThe Swiss team, meanwhile, had to replace Adrien Briffod, who had to withdraw due to a gastrointestinal infection. Simon Westermann will replace him.\n\nSwiss Olympic Chief Medical Officer Hanspeter Betschart noted that it is unclear if Briffod's infection is related to the Seine's water quality.\n\n\"A survey of my colleagues from other countries has so far not revealed any accumulation of gastrointestinal illnesses among the athletes who started the individual race last Wednesday,\" Betschart said.\n\nDespite the two illnesses, World Triathlon and Paris 2024 have said in a Sunday statement that Monday's mixed relay triathlon will proceed as planned, saying that the water quality in the Seine has improved over the past few hours.\n\n\"The latest analysis results confirm that the water quality of the Seine at the triathlon site has improved over the past few hours, and prospective analyses indicate that the water quality will be within acceptable limits by World Triathlon. As a result, World Triathlon has made the decision this evening to continue the competition,\" the statement read in part.\n\nThe individual triathlon competitions went ahead on Wednesday after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier. More rain came into Paris overnight on Tuesday ahead of the race, but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3:30 a.m. attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. respectively,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a joint statement.\n\nThe athletes had largely put their trust in organizers to ensure that the water quality was safe for them. Women's silver medal winner Julie Derron of Switzerland said the athletes believed that the race was safe based on the word of authorities.\n\n\"The swimming was fine during the race. We know that they took samples this morning. They take a lot of time to analyze, so we don't know the results obviously. We all trust the authorities and the organizers that they keep us safe. And so we had a safe race today,\" she said.\n\nAfter the race, men's gold medal winner Alex Yee was complimentary to the organizers.\n\n\"We're lucky enough to have probably the most beautiful venue of any race in the Olympics. And I guess that came with a small penalty of the risk of the Seine being dirty,\" he said.\n\nHeavy rains battered Paris last weekend, drenching the opening ceremony and raising concerns about water quality in the river, which usually declines after rainfall.\n\nTraining was canceled for two straight days last week after water quality testing deemed the water unsafe for athletes, but organizers were confident at the time that the races would go ahead as planned.\n\nThe decision to hold some swimming events in the famous river that splits Paris raised eyebrows when it was first announced. Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century but, in their desire to put the host city on full display, organizers worked up a plan to clean up the river so the world's best athletes could use it during Paris 2024.\n\nAbout $1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) had been spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games and Paris officials have made a big show of displaying its suitability. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier this month to display her confidence in the river's water quality and promised to put a swimming pool in the river after the Games. The French sports minister has also gone for a dip in the Seine.\n\nOne of the key infrastructure projects designed to help tackle pollution has been a new rainwater storage basin - called the Austerlitz basin - which can hold 20 Olympic swimming pools worth of water, according to a statement from Paris 2024.\n\nFollowing rainy weather on June 17 and 18, the basin filled to 80% capacity, successfully preventing 40,000 cubic meters (40 million liters) of wastewater and rainwater from being discharged into the Seine, according to the city of Paris.\n\nBut the water quality can change fast. Official data shows one-off rainfall events can quickly cause E. coli levels to spike again, and as recently as June 30 - following rain the previous day - E. coli levels increased to around 2000 CFU/100mL at Alexandra III Bridge, where the race is set to begin.\n\nThat's double the level needed for \"good\" water quality, as per World Triathlon standards.\n\nFor much of the month before the games, E. coli levels were above acceptable levels, which could expose athletes to serious health concerns. If E. Coli levels are above 1000 CFU/100mL, the swimming leg of the triathlon will have to be cancelled, according to World Triathlon competition rules, unless the organization's medical committee decides the race can go ahead.\n\nThe individual triathlon races took place with a 1.5-kilometer swim, followed by a 40K bike race - passing by the Le Grand Palais and the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es - before finishing with a 10K run through the heart of the city.\n\nThe mixed team relay race involving four athletes - two men and two women - will start with each team member completing a 300-meter swim, followed by a 5.8K bike ride and 1.8K run.\n\nCNN's Homero De La Fuente, Kevin Dotson and Chris Liakos contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8259171124", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:52:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:52:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:51:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/sport/paris-2024/2024/0804/1463482-illness-and-withdrawals-ahead-of-mixed-relay-triathlon/", "title": "Illness and withdrawals ahead of mixed relay triathlon", "body": "Belgium have withdrawn from Monday's mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics citing an illness for athlete Claire Michel amid reports it is a case of E. coli.\n\nThe health of athletes competing in the triathlon events at these Games has been a hot topic following concerns over the water quality of the River Seine.\n\nOn Sunday Olympic organisers cancelled the swim familiarisation session for Monday's race as the water quality levels had dropped back below the required standards following heavy rain.\n\nThe men's triathlon was postponed by one day earlier in the week to Wednesday and took place on the same day as the women's event.\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's race on Wednesday.\n\nIt is not yet certain that Monday's event will take place as scheduled.\n\nA joint statement from the Belgian Olympic Committee and Belgium Triathlon announced their withdrawal from the mixed relay.\n\nIt said: \"The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and the entourage.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and has to withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nBelgian media reported that Michel has contracted E. coli.\n\nThe team statement did not confirm that, but notably added: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for the next triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games.\n\n\"We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the format of the competitions which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, the entourage and the supporters.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Switzerland have made a change to their line-up after Adrien Briffod also fell ill, with Simon Westermann taking his place.\n\n\"I don't really know if my condition is linked to the quality of the water in the Seine,\" Briffod told Le Matin.\n\nHeavy rain hit Paris on Wednesday and Thursday, causing levels of bacteria in the water to rise.\n\nPrior to the men's and women's events taking place on Wednesday, athletes had been unable to train in the river because the water quality had not passed the required tests.\n\nBritain's athletes are all understood to have avoided any ill effects from swimming in the water but all nations have faced disruption to their preparations.\n\nOrganisers issued a statement on Sunday morning which said: \"(The) decision has been made to cancel the swim leg of the triathlon familiarisation, which was due to be held on 4 August at 8am (7am Irish time).\n\n\"Given the heavy rain over the nights of 31 July and 1 August, which had been particularly intense upstream of Paris, we still see impact on the water quality in our venue.\n\n\"We are expecting an improvement on the conditions in the next hours, but not to a level to which the swim familiarisation planned for (Sunday) can take place.\"\n\nSpeaking at Sunday morning's IOC briefing, Paris 2024 director of communications Anne Descamps added: \"We are expecting improvement regarding the weather forecast. As we've seen the sun and the heat have a very positive impact.\n\n\"Hopefully we can organise the competition tomorrow. We'll take the decision as planned tomorrow morning regarding the latest samples.\"", "source": {"uri": "rte.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "RTE.ie"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443918097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:49:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:49:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:40:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/mixed-relay-ahead-despite-withdrawal-224031794.html", "title": "Mixed relay to go ahead despite withdrawal of Belgium due to 'E. coli' illness", "body": "Mixed relay to go ahead despite withdrawal of Belgium due to 'E. coli' illness\n\nPA Sport staff\n\n5 August 2024 at 0:40 am\n\nThe Olympic triathlon mixed relay will go ahead on Monday in Paris but without Belgium, who have withdrawn citing an illness for athlete Claire Michel amid reports it is a case of E. coli.\n\nThe health of athletes competing in the triathlon events at these Games has been a hot topic following concerns over the water quality of the River Seine.\n\nOlympic organisers cancelled the swim familiarisation sessions over the weekend as the water quality levels had dropped back below the required standards following heavy rain.\n\nBut on Sunday evening it was announced the mixed relay would take place as scheduled on Monday morning.\n\n\"The latest test results confirm that Seine water quality levels at the triathlon venue have improved in recent hours, with forward-looking analysis indicating that water quality will be within the levels acceptable by World Triathlon,\" read a statement.\n\nThe men's triathlon was postponed by one day earlier in the week to Wednesday and took place on the same day as the women's event.\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's race on Wednesday.\n\nA joint statement from the Belgian Olympic Committee (COIB) and Belgium Triathlon announced their withdrawal from the mixed relay.\n\nIt said: \"The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and the entourage.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and has to withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nBelgian media reported that Michel has contracted E. coli.\n\nThe team statement did not confirm that, but notably added: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for the next triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games.\n\nGames organisers did not confirm or deny the E. coli reports, but did state that the 35-year-old has not been hospitalised.\n\nView this post on Instagram\n\nA post shared by Belgian Hammers (@belgianhammers)\n\n\"We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the format of the competitions which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, the entourage and the supporters.\"\n\n\"Paris 2024 wishes the athlete involved a quick recovery and will seek regular updates on their health,\" a spokesperson said. \"Paris 2024 wishes to remind everyone that the health and well-being of athletes is our top priority.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Switzerland have made a change to their line-up after Adrien Briffod also fell ill, with Simon Westermann taking his place.\n\n\"I don't really know if my condition is linked to the quality of the water in the Seine,\" Briffod told Le Matin.\n\nHeavy rain hit Paris on Wednesday and Thursday, causing levels of bacteria in the water to rise.\n\nPrior to the men's and women's events taking place on Wednesday, athletes had been unable to train in the river because the water quality had not passed the required tests.\n\nBritain's athletes are all understood to have avoided any ill effects from swimming in the water, but all nations have faced disruption to their preparations.\n\nBritain won gold in the inaugural Olympic mixed relay in Tokyo and will be among the favourites to secure another medal.\n\nIn Wednesday's triathlons, Great Britain's Alex Yee won a gold medal in the men's race and Beth Potter won bronze in the women's competition.\n\nYee and Potter will compete along with Georgia Taylor-Brown and Sam Dickinson.", {"uri": "2024-08-444358050", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:58:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:58:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:56:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/health/2024/08/05/belgium-withdraws-from-triathlon-mixed-relay-after-athlete-gets-sick", "title": "Belgium withdraws from triathlon mixed relay after athlete gets sick", "body": "Belgium withdrew from the mixed relay that included swimming in the Seine.\n\nBelgium did not take part in the triathlon mixed relay in Paris on Monday, the Belgian Olympic Committee said after one of the country's athletes became sick and withdrew from the competition.\n\nThe withdrawal of the athlete Claire Michel prompted renewed debate about the water quality of the Seine despite coming several days after she swam in the river.\n\nPierre Rabadan, deputy mayor of Paris in charge of sport, the Olympic and Paralympic Games and the Seine, told FranceInfo on Monday morning that other athletes were sick in the Olympic village who did not swim in the river.\n\n\"Nothing allows us to say that there is a link with the quality of the water,\" Rabadan said of Michel's illness, adding that they did not know the cause.\n\nOrganisers had said that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nThe water results on Sunday night indicated the quality at the triathlon site had improved over recent hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of faecal bacteria, including E. coli, in the Seine's waters. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nWorld Triathlon's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection and the weather forecast when determining whether to go forward with a race.\n\nThe decisions have generally been made at early morning meetings on the day of the event. But in announcing Sunday night that the race would happen Monday, organisers said they were responding to requests from athletes to give them more time to prepare.\n\nLeading up to the individual triathlon events, water quality concerns prompted organisers to cancel the swimming portion of two test runs meant to allow athletes to familiarise themselves with the course and to delay the men's race by a day.\n\nTest swims in the Seine scheduled for Saturday and Sunday before the triathlon mixed relay were also cancelled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nThe Belgian Olympic committee and \"Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for the next triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games,\" the organisations said in a statement.\n\nThis includes making sure \"training days, competition days and the competition format, [are] clarified in advance [to] ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, their entourage and the supporters\".", "source": {"uri": "8259070672", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:30:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:30:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:29:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/belgium-e-coli-paris-switzerland-ioc-b2591038.html", "title": "Belgium pull out of mixed relay after triathlete falls ill 'with E.coli'", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nBelgium have withdrawn from Monday's mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics citing an illness for athlete Claire Michel amid reports it is a case of E. coli.\n\nThe health of athletes competing in the triathlon events at these Games has been a hot topic following concerns over the water quality of the River Seine.\n\nOn Sunday Olympic organisers cancelled the swim familiarisation session for Monday's race as the water quality levels had dropped back below the required standards following heavy rain.\n\nThe men's triathlon was postponed by one day earlier in the week to Wednesday and took place on the same day as the women's event.\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's race on Wednesday.\n\nIt is not yet certain that Monday's event will take place as scheduled.\n\nA joint statement from the Belgian Olympic Committee (COIB) and Belgium Triathlon announced their withdrawal from the mixed relay.\n\nIt said: \"The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and the entourage.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and has to withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nBelgian media reported that Michel has contracted E. coli.\n\nThe team statement did not confirm that, but notably added: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for the next triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games.\n\n\"We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the format of the competitions which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, the entourage and the supporters.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Switzerland have made a change to their line-up after Adrien Briffod also fell ill, with Simon Westermann taking his place.\n\n\"I don't really know if my condition is linked to the quality of the water in the Seine,\" Briffod told Le Matin.\n\nHeavy rain hit Paris on Wednesday and Thursday, causing levels of bacteria in the water to rise.\n\nPrior to the men's and women's events taking place on Wednesday, athletes had been unable to train in the river because the water quality had not passed the required tests.\n\nBritain's athletes are all understood to have avoided any ill effects from swimming in the water but all nations have faced disruption to their preparations.\n\nOrganisers issued a statement on Sunday morning which said: \"(The) decision has been made to cancel the swim leg of the triathlon familiarisation, which was due to be held on August 4 at 8am (7am BST).\n\n\"Given the heavy rain over the nights of July 31 and August 1, which had been particularly intense upstream of Paris, we still see impact on the water quality in our venue.\n\n\"We are expecting an improvement on the conditions in the next hours, but not to a level to which the swim familiarisation planned for (Sunday) can take place.\"\n\nSpeaking at Sunday morning's IOC briefing, Paris 2024 director of communications Anne Descamps added: \"We are expecting improvement regarding the weather forecast. As we've seen the sun and the heat have a very positive impact.\n\n\"Hopefully we can organise the competition tomorrow. We'll take the decision as planned tomorrow morning regarding the latest samples.\"\n\nBritain won gold in the inaugural Olympic mixed relay in Tokyo and will be among the favourites to secure another medal.\n\nIn Wednesday's triathlons, Great Britain's Alex Yee won a gold medal in the men's race and Beth Potter won bronze in the women's competition.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", {"uri": "2024-08-443791830", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:07:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:07:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:19:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/belgium-drops-out-of-mixed-triathlon-and-switzerland-shuffles-line-up-after-athletes-fall-ill/article_8ace8430-d02d-5a5f-aa28-dfc7a0242b98.html", "title": "Belgium drops out of mixed triathlon and Switzerland shuffles line-up after athletes fall ill following race in River Seine", "body": "Paris (CNN) -- Belgium has withdrawn from the mixed relay triathlon race on Monday and Switzerland has had to mix up its roster after athletes from both countries fell ill following the initial triathlon races last week.\n\nBelgium announced it was dropping out of the race after one of its triathletes, Claire Michel, has fallen ill, its National Olympic Committee said in a statement. The statement did not specify Michel's illness, which was reported days after she swam in the River Seine during the women's triathlon on Wednesday.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon must unfortunately announce that the 'Belgian Hammers' will not be starting the mixed relay at the Paris Olympic Games tomorrow. The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's triathlon competition on Wednesday.\n\nThe statement also had pointed words that appeared to be aimed at organizers: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games such as guaranteeing training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes and support personnel.\"\n\nThe Swiss team, meanwhile, had to replace Adrien Briffod, who had to withdraw due to a gastrointestinal infection. Simon Westermann will replace him.\n\nSwiss Olympic Chief Medical Officer Hanspeter Betschart noted that it is unclear if Briffod's infection is related to the Seine's water quality.\n\n\"A survey of my colleagues from other countries has so far not revealed any accumulation of gastrointestinal illnesses among the athletes who started the individual race last Wednesday,\" Betschart said.\n\nTriathlons proceeded amid water quality concerns\n\nThe individual triathlon competitions went ahead in Paris after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier. More rain came into Paris overnight ahead of the race, but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3:30 a.m. attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. respectively,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a joint statement.\n\nThe athletes had largely put their trust in organizers to ensure that the water quality was safe for them. Women's silver medal winner Julie Derron of Switzerland said the athletes believed that the race was safe based on the word of authorities.\n\n\"The swimming was fine during the race. We know that they took samples this morning. They take a lot of time to analyze, so we don't know the results obviously. We all trust the authorities and the organizers that they keep us safe. And so we had a safe race today,\" she said.\n\nAfter the race, men's gold medal winner Alex Yee was complimentary to the organizers.\n\n\"We're lucky enough to have probably the most beautiful venue of any race in the Olympics. And I guess that came with a small penalty of the risk of the Seine being dirty,\" he said.\n\nHeavy rains battered Paris last weekend, drenching the opening ceremony and raising concerns about water quality in the river, which usually declines after rainfall.\n\nTraining was canceled for two straight days last week after water quality testing deemed the water unsafe for athletes, but organizers were confident at the time that the races would go ahead as planned.\n\nSeine clean-up\n\nThe decision to hold some swimming events in the famous river that splits Paris raised eyebrows when it was first announced. Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century but, in their desire to put the host city on full display, organizers worked up a plan to clean up the river so the world's best athletes could use it during Paris 2024.\n\nAbout $1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) had been spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games and Paris officials have made a big show of displaying its suitability. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier this month to display her confidence in the river's water quality and promised to put a swimming pool in the river after the Games. The French sports minister has also gone for a dip in the Seine.\n\nOne of the key infrastructure projects designed to help tackle pollution has been a new rainwater storage basin - called the Austerlitz basin - which can hold 20 Olympic swimming pools worth of water, according to a statement from Paris 2024.\n\nFollowing rainy weather on June 17 and 18, the basin filled to 80% capacity, successfully preventing 40,000 cubic meters (40 million liters) of wastewater and rainwater from being discharged into the Seine, according to the city of Paris.\n\nBut the water quality can change fast. Official data shows one-off rainfall events can quickly cause E. coli levels to spike again, and as recently as June 30 - following rain the previous day - E. coli levels increased to around 2000 CFU/100mL at Alexandra III Bridge, where the race is set to begin.\n\nThat's double the level needed for \"good\" water quality, as per World Triathlon standards.\n\nFor much of the month before the games, E. coli levels were above acceptable levels, which could expose athletes to serious health concerns. If E. Coli levels are above 1000 CFU/100mL, the swimming leg of the triathlon will have to be cancelled, according to World Triathlon competition rules, unless the organization's medical committee decides the race can go ahead.\n\nThe individual triathlon races took place with a 1.5-kilometer swim, followed by a 40K bike race - passing by the Le Grand Palais and the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es - before finishing with a 10K run through the heart of the city.\n\nThe mixed team relay race involving four athletes - two men and two women - will start with each team member completing a 300-meter swim, followed by a 5.8K bike ride and 1.8K run.\n\nCNN's Homero De La Fuente, Kevin Dotson and Chris Liakos contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All rights reserved.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. E.coli'", "body": "Belgium pull out of mixed relay after triathlete falls ill 'with E.coli'\n\nPA Sport staff\n\n4 August 2024 at 7:57 pm\n\nBelgium have withdrawn from Monday's mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics citing an illness for athlete Claire Michel amid reports it is a case of E. coli.\n\nThe health of athletes competing in the triathlon events at these Games has been a hot topic following concerns over the water quality of the River Seine.\n\nOn Sunday Olympic organisers cancelled the swim familiarisation session for Monday's race as the water quality levels had dropped back below the required standards following heavy rain.\n\nThe men's triathlon was postponed by one day earlier in the week to Wednesday and took place on the same day as the women's event.\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's race on Wednesday.\n\nIt is not yet certain that Monday's event will take place as scheduled.\n\nA joint statement from the Belgian Olympic Committee (COIB) and Belgium Triathlon announced their withdrawal from the mixed relay.\n\nIt said: \"The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and the entourage.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and has to withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nBelgian media reported that Michel has contracted E. coli.\n\nThe team statement did not confirm that, but notably added: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for the next triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games.\n\n\"We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the format of the competitions which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, the entourage and the supporters.\"\n\nHeavy rain hit Paris on Wednesday and Thursday, causing levels of bacteria in the water to rise.\n\nPrior to the men's and women's events taking place on Wednesday, athletes had been unable to train in the river because the water quality had not passed the required tests.\n\nBritain's athletes are all understood to have avoided any ill effects from swimming in the water but all nations have faced disruption to their preparations.\n\nOrganisers issued a statement on Sunday morning which said: \"(The) decision has been made to cancel the swim leg of the triathlon familiarisation, which was due to be held on August 4 at 8am (7am BST).\n\n\"Given the heavy rain over the nights of July 31 and August 1, which had been particularly intense upstream of Paris, we still see impact on the water quality in our venue.\n\n\"We are expecting an improvement on the conditions in the next hours, but not to a level to which the swim familiarisation planned for (Sunday) can take place.\"\n\nSpeaking at Sunday morning's IOC briefing, Paris 2024 director of communications Anne Descamps added: \"We are expecting improvement regarding the weather forecast. As we've seen the sun and the heat have a very positive impact.\n\n\"Hopefully we can organise the competition tomorrow. We'll take the decision as planned tomorrow morning regarding the latest samples.\"\n\nBritain won gold in the inaugural Olympic mixed relay in Tokyo and will be among the favourites to secure another medal.\n\nIn Wednesday's triathlons, Great Britain's Alex Yee won a gold medal in the men's race and Beth Potter won bronze in the women's competition.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": {"uri": "8258924975", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:30:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:30:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:29:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://ksltv.com/667704/belgium-withdraws-from-mixed-relay-triathlon-after-triathlete-falls-ill-days-after-swimming-in-the-seine/", "title": "Belgium withdraws from mixed relay triathlon after triathlete falls ill days after swimming in the Seine", "body": "Paris (CNN) -- Belgium has withdrawn from the mixed relay triathlon race on Monday after one of its triathletes, Claire Michel, has fallen ill, its National Olympic Committee said in a statement.\n\nThe statement did not specify Michel's illness, which was reported days after she swam in the River Seine during the women's triathlon on Wednesday.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon must unfortunately announce that the 'Belgian Hammers' will not be starting the mixed relay at the Paris Olympic Games tomorrow. The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's triathlon competition on Wednesday.\n\nThe statement also had pointed words that appeared to be aimed at organizers: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games such as guaranteeing training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes and support personnel.\"\n\nThe triathlon competitions went ahead in Paris after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier. More rain came into Paris overnight ahead of the race, but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3:30 a.m. attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. respectively,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a joint statement.\n\nThe athletes had largely put their trust in organizers to ensure that the water quality was safe for them. Women's silver medal winner Julie Derron of Switzerland said the athletes believed that the race was safe based on the word of authorities.\n\n\"The swimming was fine during the race. We know that they took samples this morning. They take a lot of time to analyze, so we don't know the results obviously. We all trust the authorities and the organizers that they keep us safe. And so we had a safe race today,\" she said.\n\nAfter the race, men's gold medal winner Alex Yee was complimentary to the organizers.\n\n\"We're lucky enough to have probably the most beautiful venue of any race in the Olympics. And I guess that came with a small penalty of the risk of the Seine being dirty,\" he said.\n\nHeavy rains battered Paris last weekend, drenching the opening ceremony and raising concerns about water quality in the river, which usually declines after rainfall.\n\nTraining was canceled for two straight days last week after water quality testing deemed the water unsafe for athletes, but organizers were confident at the time that the races would go ahead as planned.\n\nThe decision to hold some swimming events in the famous river that splits Paris raised eyebrows when it was first announced. Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century but, in their desire to put the host city on full display, organizers worked up a plan to clean up the river so the world's best athletes could use it during Paris 2024.\n\nAbout $1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) had been spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games and Paris officials have made a big show of displaying its suitability. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier this month to display her confidence in the river's water quality and promised to put a swimming pool in the river after the Games. The French sports minister has also gone for a dip in the Seine.\n\nOne of the key infrastructure projects designed to help tackle pollution has been a new rainwater storage basin - called the Austerlitz basin - which can hold 20 Olympic swimming pools worth of water, according to a statement from Paris 2024.\n\nFollowing rainy weather on June 17 and 18, the basin filled to 80% capacity, successfully preventing 40,000 cubic meters (40 million liters) of wastewater and rainwater from being discharged into the Seine, according to the city of Paris.\n\nBut the water quality can change fast. Official data shows one-off rainfall events can quickly cause E. coli levels to spike again, and as recently as June 30 - following rain the previous day - E. coli levels increased to around 2000 CFU/100mL at Alexandra III Bridge, where the race is set to begin.\n\nThat's double the level needed for \"good\" water quality, as per World Triathlon standards.\n\nFor much of the month before the games, E. coli levels were above acceptable levels, which could expose athletes to serious health concerns. If E. Coli levels are above 1000 CFU/100mL, the swimming leg of the triathlon will have to be cancelled, according to World Triathlon competition rules, unless the organization's medical committee decides the race can go ahead.\n\nThe individual triathlon races took place with a 1.5-kilometer swim, followed by a 40K bike race - passing by the Le Grand Palais and the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es - before finishing with a 10K run through the heart of the city.\n\nThe mixed team relay race involving four athletes - two men and two women - will start with each team member completing a 300-meter swim, followed by a 5.8K bike ride and 1.8K run.", "source": {"uri": "ksltv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KSLTV.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": relay after triathlete falls ill 'with E.coli'", "body": "Claire Michel is ill and the Belgian Olympic Committee has called for 'lessons to be learned'.\n\nBelgium have withdrawn from Monday's mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics citing an illness for athlete Claire Michel amid reports it is a case of E. coli.\n\nThe health of athletes competing in the triathlon events at these Games has been a hot topic following concerns over the water quality of the River Seine.\n\nOn Sunday Olympic organisers cancelled the swim familiarisation session for Monday's race as the water quality levels had dropped back below the required standards following heavy rain.\n\nThe men's triathlon was postponed by one day earlier in the week to Wednesday and took place on the same day as the women's event.\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's race on Wednesday.\n\nA joint statement from the Belgian Olympic Committee (COIB) and Belgium Triathlon announced their withdrawal from the mixed relay.\n\nIt said: \"The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and the entourage.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and has to withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nBelgian media reported that Michel has contracted E. coli.\n\nThe team statement did not confirm that, but notably added: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for the next triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games.\n\n\"We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the format of the competitions which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, the entourage and the supporters.\"\n\nHeavy rain hit Paris on Wednesday and Thursday, causing levels of bacteria in the water to rise.\n\nBritain's athletes are all understood to have avoided any ill effects from swimming in the water but all nations have faced disruption to their preparations.\n\nOrganisers issued a statement on Sunday morning which said: \"(The) decision has been made to cancel the swim leg of the triathlon familiarisation, which was due to be held on August 4 at 8am (7am BST).\n\n\"Given the heavy rain over the nights of July 31 and August 1, which had been particularly intense upstream of Paris, we still see impact on the water quality in our venue.\n\n\"We are expecting an improvement on the conditions in the next hours, but not to a level to which the swim familiarisation planned for (Sunday) can take place.\"\n\n\"Hopefully we can organise the competition tomorrow. We'll take the decision as planned tomorrow morning regarding the latest samples.\"\n\nBritain won gold in the inaugural Olympic mixed relay in Tokyo and will be among the favourites to secure another medal.\n\nIn Wednesday's triathlons, Great Britain's Alex Yee won a gold medal in the men's race and Beth Potter won bronze in the women's competition.", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", {"uri": "2024-08-444133837", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:18:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:18:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:09:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/olympic-triathlon-mixed-relay-gets-underway-with-swims-in-the-seine-amid-water-quality-concerns/article_7c5c463e-ebd0-56ef-9816-a3ba4e63cd14.html", "title": "Olympic triathlon mixed relay gets underway with swims in the Seine amid water quality concerns", "body": "FILE - Australia's Natalie Van Coevorden (15), Belgium's Claire Michel (5) and Ekaterina Shabalina, of Kazakhstan (32) compete in the swim leg of the women's individual triathlon competition at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Wednesday, July 31, 2024, in Paris, France. Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday Aug.4, 2024 that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon at the Paris Olympics after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River fell ill. Claire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement.\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Olympic triathletes plunged into the Seine River Monday morning as the mixed relay event got underway after days of uncertainty over water quality in the long-polluted Paris waterway.\n\nThe plan to hold the swimming portion of the triathlons and the marathon swimming events in the Seine was an ambitious one. Swimming in the river has, with some exceptions, been off-limits since 1923 because it has been too toxic.\n\nRepresentatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities met Sunday night to review water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over the preceding hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon by Monday morning, they said in a statement.\n\nThe decision to allow the event to go forward with swims in the Seine came after Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon after one of its competitors who swam in the river last week fell ill. It was not clear whether her illness had anything to do with her swim in the Seine.\n\nParis spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) on infrastructure improvements to clean up the river that flows through its center. That included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nHeavy rains that have fallen off and on during the Games have caused headaches for organizers as they result in elevated levels of fecal bacteria, including E. coli and enterococci, flowing into the river.\n\nBut organizers have continued to express confidence that warm temperatures and the sun's ultraviolet rays would combine to kill enough of the germs ahead of each event set to include a swim in the Seine.\n\nAthletes swam in the river for the men's and women's individual triathlons Wednesday, though the men's race had been delayed by a day because of the water quality. Elevated bacteria levels in the waterway have caused cancellations of the swimming portion of training sessions for the relay event.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nThe triathlon mixed relay involves four-person teams made up of two men and two women, with each athlete swimming for 300 meters (yards), cycling for 6.8 kilometers (4.2 miles) and running for 2 kilometers (1.2 miles).\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", {"uri": "2024-08-444156796", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:46:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:46:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:36:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/sports/sport-others/paris-olympics-belgium-withdraws-from-mixed-relay-triathlon-after-athlete-fall-sick-after-swimming-in-river-seine-9495833/", "title": "Paris Olympics: Belgium withdraws from mixed relay triathlon after athlete falls ill after swimming in River Seine", "body": "Claire Michel, one of the athletes in the mixed relay team, unfortunately has to withdraw from the competition due to illness.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement.\n\nThe Belgian committee's statement did not elaborate on Michel's illness but it comes after concerns over the river's water quality. Organizers had said that water quality tests done the day of the individual triathlon races showed \"very good\" bacteria levels.\n\nLeading up to the individual triathlon events, water quality concerns prompted organizers to cancel the swimming portion of two test runs meant to allow athletes to familiarize themselves with the course and also to delay the men's race by a day. Test swims in the Seine scheduled for Saturday and Sunday before the triathlon mixed relay were also canceled because of bacteria levels in the water.\n\nThe Belgian committee said it \"hopes that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games. We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, entourage and supporters.\"\n\nOn Sunday night, representatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities reviewed water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over recent hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Indian Express"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triathlon_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics_\u2013_Mixed_relay", "type": "wiki", "news/Sports", "wgt": 83}], "image": "https://images.indianexpress.com/2024/08/Claire-Michel.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9788308", "eventUri": "eng-9788308", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2156862745098039, "wgt": 194, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8258943043", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:52:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:52:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:51:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/belgium-withdraws-from-mixed-relay-triathlon-after-triathlete-falls-ill-days-after-swimming-in-the/article_a0a43e47-038a-5282-a6b6-1068a8dabc45.html", "title": "Belgium withdraws from mixed relay triathlon after triathlete falls ill days after swimming in the Seine", "body": "Paris (CNN) -- Belgium has withdrawn from the mixed relay triathlon race on Monday after one of its triathletes, Claire Michel, has fallen ill, its National Olympic Committee said in a statement.\n\nThe statement did not specify Michel's illness, which was reported days after she swam in the River Seine during the women's triathlon on Wednesday.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon must unfortunately announce that the 'Belgian Hammers' will not be starting the mixed relay at the Paris Olympic Games tomorrow. The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nMichel finished 38th in the women's triathlon competition on Wednesday.\n\nThe statement also had pointed words that appeared to be aimed at organizers: \"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games such as guaranteeing training days, competition days and the competition format, which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes and support personnel.\"\n\nTriathlons proceeded amid water quality concerns\n\nThe triathlon competitions went ahead in Paris after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier. More rain came into Paris overnight ahead of the race, but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3:30 a.m. attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. respectively,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a joint statement.\n\nThe athletes had largely put their trust in organizers to ensure that the water quality was safe for them. Women's silver medal winner Julie Derron of Switzerland said the athletes believed that the race was safe based on the word of authorities.\n\n\"The swimming was fine during the race. We know that they took samples this morning. They take a lot of time to analyze, so we don't know the results obviously. We all trust the authorities and the organizers that they keep us safe. And so we had a safe race today,\" she said.\n\nAfter the race, men's gold medal winner Alex Yee was complimentary to the organizers.\n\n\"We're lucky enough to have probably the most beautiful venue of any race in the Olympics. And I guess that came with a small penalty of the risk of the Seine being dirty,\" he said.\n\nHeavy rains battered Paris last weekend, drenching the opening ceremony and raising concerns about water quality in the river, which usually declines after rainfall.\n\nTraining was canceled for two straight days last week after water quality testing deemed the water unsafe for athletes, but organizers were confident at the time that the races would go ahead as planned.\n\nSeine clean-up\n\nThe decision to hold some swimming events in the famous river that splits Paris raised eyebrows when it was first announced. Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century but, in their desire to put the host city on full display, organizers worked up a plan to clean up the river so the world's best athletes could use it during Paris 2024.\n\nAbout $1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) had been spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games and Paris officials have made a big show of displaying its suitability. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier this month to display her confidence in the river's water quality and promised to put a swimming pool in the river after the Games. The French sports minister has also gone for a dip in the Seine.\n\nOne of the key infrastructure projects designed to help tackle pollution has been a new rainwater storage basin - called the Austerlitz basin - which can hold 20 Olympic swimming pools worth of water, according to a statement from Paris 2024.\n\nFollowing rainy weather on June 17 and 18, the basin filled to 80% capacity, successfully preventing 40,000 cubic meters (40 million liters) of wastewater and rainwater from being discharged into the Seine, according to the city of Paris.\n\nBut the water quality can change fast. Official data shows one-off rainfall events can quickly cause E. coli levels to spike again, and as recently as June 30 - following rain the previous day - E. coli levels increased to around 2000 CFU/100mL at Alexandra III Bridge, where the race is set to begin.\n\nThat's double the level needed for \"good\" water quality, as per World Triathlon standards.\n\nFor much of the month before the games, E. coli levels were above acceptable levels, which could expose athletes to serious health concerns. If E. Coli levels are above 1000 CFU/100mL, the swimming leg of the triathlon will have to be cancelled, according to World Triathlon competition rules, unless the organization's medical committee decides the race can go ahead.\n\nThe individual triathlon races took place with a 1.5-kilometer swim, followed by a 40K bike race - passing by the Le Grand Palais and the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es - before finishing with a 10K run through the heart of the city.\n\nThe mixed team relay race involving four athletes - two men and two women - will start with each team member completing a 300-meter swim, followed by a 5.8K bike ride and 1.8K run.\n\nCNN's Homero De La Fuente, Kevin Dotson and Chris Liakos contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company.
