{"uri": "2024-08-444192587", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:24:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:24:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:21:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.news18.com/olympics/paris-olympic-triathlon-mixed-relay-gets-underway-with-swims-in-seine-amid-water-quality-concerns-8990495.html", "title": "Paris Olympic Triathlon Mixed Relay Gets Underway With Swims in Seine Amid Water Quality Concerns", "body": "The triathlon mixed relay involves four-person teams made up of two men and two women. (Getty Images)\n\nOlympic triathletes plunged into the Seine River Monday morning as the mixed relay event got underway after organizers said the bacteria levels in the long-polluted Paris waterway were at acceptable levels.\n\nAlso Read: 'Sreejesh is the God of Indian Hockey'\n\nThe plan to hold the swimming portion of the triathlons and the marathon swimming events in the Seine was an ambitious one. Swimming in the river has, with some exceptions, been off-limits since 1923 because it has been too toxic.\n\nRepresentatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities met Sunday night to review water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over the preceding hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon by Monday morning, they said in a statement.\n\nThe decision to allow the event to go forward with swims in the Seine came after Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon after one of its competitors who swam in the river last week fell ill. It was not clear whether her illness had anything to do with her swim in the Seine.\n\nParis spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) on infrastructure improvements to clean up the river that flows through its center. That included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nHeavy rains that have fallen off and on during the Games have caused headaches for organizers as they result in elevated levels of fecal bacteria, including E. coli and enterococci, flowing into the river. Drenching rains fell Thursday night, but conditions had otherwise been dry except for light rain Saturday evening. The sun shone brightly as the race unfolded Monday and athletes said organizers reassured them that there were no concerns with water quality.\n\nOrganizers have continued to express confidence that warm temperatures and the sun's ultraviolet rays would combine to kill enough of the germs ahead of each event set to include a swim in the Seine.\n\nAthletes swam in the river for the men's and women's individual triathlons Wednesday, though the men's race had been delayed by a day because of the water quality. Elevated bacteria levels in the waterway have caused cancellations of the swimming portion of training sessions for the relay event.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nThe triathlon mixed relay involves four-person teams made up of two men and two women, with each athlete swimming for 300 meters (yards), cycling for 6.8 kilometers (4.2 miles) and running for 2 kilometers (1.2 miles).", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": UrduPoint", "body": "Paris, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 5th Aug, 2024) The Olympic triathlon mixed relay will go ahead as planned Monday, organisers said, despite two days of training in the River Seine being cancelled and a Belgian triathlete falling sick.\n\n\"The latest test results confirm that the water quality of the Seine at the triathlon site has improved over the last hours, and the prospective tests indicate the water quality will be within the acceptable limits according to World Triathlon,\" Paris Games organisers said in a statement on Sunday.\n\nA decision was initially due to be made overnight Sunday to Monday based on bacteriological results from 24 hours before, but it was brought forward at the request of the triathlon teams to allow athletes more time to prepare.\n\nThe men's triathlon was postponed from Tuesday to Wednesday earlier this week because of pollution problems, with competitors only finding out around 4:00 am on the morning of the scheduled race.\n\n\"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that the lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympics,\" the committee said in a statement.", "source": {"uri": Swimming in the river has, with some exceptions, been off-limits since 1923 because it has been too toxic.\n\nRepresentatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities met Sunday night to review water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over the preceding hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon by Monday morning, they said in a statement.\n\nThe decision to allow the event to go forward with swims in the Seine came after Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon after one of its competitors who swam in the river last week fell ill. as triathletes hospitalised", "body": "Paris organisers' worst fears have come true after mutiple athletes fell seriously ill after competing in the triathlon.\n\nConcerns were raised going into the Olympics over the events taking place in the Seine River and now the reality has hit.\n\nBelgium were forced to pull of of the mixed triathlon relay after one of their athletes was hospitalised with an E. coli infection.\n\nClaire Michel, 35, has been sick for the past four days, an illness that has now ruled her out of the race entirely.\n\nWith Belgium unable to replace her in their four-person team, they have been forced to withdraw.\n\nAlong with Michel, Swiss triathlete Adrien Briffod has fallen seriously ill following the men's individual event, according to reports.\n\nThe Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee released a statement saying: \"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions.\n\n\"We are thinking of training days that can be guaranteed, competition days and formats that are clear in advance and circumstances that do not lead to uncertainty among athletes, entourage and fans.\"\n\nMichel's E. coli infection comes after pollution in the River Seine led to the men's individual event being postponed.\n\nIt was pushed back by a day, before Team GB's Alex Yee eventually claimed the gold medal in the event.\n\nGreat Britian are one of the favourites to secure the gold medal in the mixed relay alongside hosts France.\n\nHowever, fears are growing that the event could be cancelled after athletes were not allowed a practice swim due once again to poor water quality.\n\nHeavy rain in Paris has increased E. coli levels and other bacteria in the river.\n\nSwimming in the river has been banned since 1923 due to the poor water quality and health hazards.\n\nBut ahead of the Games the government splurged $1.5 billion in an attempt to clean the quality up. Despite the extensive efforts the results have fallen short of expectations.\n\nBelgian triathlete Jolien Vermeylen, a teammate of the hospitalised Michel, was less than impressed with the water when she swam in the river.\n\nSpeaking to VTM after the women's race, she said: \"I drank a lot of water, so we'll know tomorrow if I'm sick or not.\n\n\"It doesn't taste like Coca-Cola or Sprite, of course.\n\n\"While swimming under the bridge, I felt and saw things that we shouldn't think about too much.\n\n\"The Seine has been dirty for a hundred years, so they can't say that the safety of the athletes is a priority. {"uri": "2024-08-444385255", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:20:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:20:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:03:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.wfxg.com/news/germany-wins-illness-affected-olympic-mixed-team-relay-triathlon/article_0890f9ed-c6c2-5650-9ab3-54db487149cf.html", "title": "Germany wins illness-affected Olympic mixed team relay triathlon", "body": "Germany won gold in the mixed triathlon relay on Monday at the Paris Olympics, with the event disrupted by illnesses that saw at least three teams report sick team members who swam in the River Seine last week.\n\nIn a thrilling climax to the team race through central Paris, Germany's Laura Lindemann won a sprint finish, narrowly edging out Taylor Knibb from the United States in second and Beth Potter from Britain in third.\n\nThe Belgian team did not race at all after their athlete Claire Michel fell sick, reportedly with E.Coli, having swum in the Seine during the women's individual triathlon last Wednesday.\n\nThe Swiss team also had to bring in a replacement after their racer Adrien Briffod suffered a gastrointestinal infection, while Norwegian competitor Vetle Bergsvik Thorn told AFP he too had been stricken with a stomach bug after the men's race last week.\n\n\"I was sick for about 12 hours, overnight from Friday to Saturday,\" he said. \"I don't know if it was food poisoning or from the Seine. Obviously it wasn't the best preparation for today.\"\n\nThe relay is a four-person sprint triathlon, with Monday's race seeing two men and two women completing a 300-metre swim in the Seine, a seven-kilometre (4.3-mile) bike ride through central Paris and a 1.8 km run.\n\nThe Seine has been the focus of attention during the Paris triathlon events with the waterway consistently failing water quality tests despite a 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) upgrade to improve the Paris sewerage and water treatment systems.\n\nThe men's race last week had to be delayed by 24 hours and no training has been possible since the start of the Games on July 28, with many athletes again surprised by the strength of the current on Monday.\n\n\"It takes some courage to swim and the ability of a good swimmer to navigate it,\" victorious German Tim Hellwig told reporters.\n\nOrganisers have stressed that the illnesses cannot be attributed to the Seine and Hellwig said he felt confident in the water tests overseen by international governing body World Triathlon.\n\n\"No-one was afraid to jump in. We were all happy to have a race,\" he added, saying that he woke up fine after last week's men's event.\n\n\"If like 99 percent of the athletes don't have any problems, I think it's fine,\" he said.\n\n- Safety -\n\nOn the eve of Monday's relay, the Belgian National Olympic Committee (COIB) revealed that Michel had fallen sick in a statement that also criticised the organisation of the triathlon at the Paris Games.\n\n\"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that the lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympics,\" the committee said.\n\nOther racers have also expressed frustration that decisions on whether the river could be used for the training and competitions were taken in the middle of the night, while organisers had threatened to scrap the swimming leg completely if the river remained too dirty.\n\n\"I don't want to be too negative. However I do think if a situation like this happens again at the Olympics, they should have a backup venue,\" US silver medallist Morgan Pearson told reporters.\n\n\"I don't think any of us are like 'I'm not going to race because of the chance of E. coli'. It's the Olympics. But that shows the liberty they took,\" he added.\n\nHeavy rainstorms overwhelm Paris's sewerage system, leading to discharges of untreated waste water that send levels of bacteria such as E.Coli spiking.\n\nParis has been drenched by two major downpours since the Olympics started, on the night of the opening ceremony and again last Thursday evening.\n\nThe Paris 2024 organising committee said in a statement that testing on the day of the men's and women's triathlon last week had shown that the quality of the water was \"very good\" based on World Triathlon's criteria.\n\n\"The decision on whether to proceed with an event is taken by the international federation, World Triathlon, in coordination with Paris 2024, and based on the test results and a range of (notably health) criteria,\" it said.\n\n\"Paris 2024 wishes to remind everyone that the health and wellbeing of athletes is our top priority,\" it added.\n\nadp/gj", "source": {"uri": "wfxg.com", "dataType": "news", "title": However, organisers have confirmed the mixed relay will take place at 8am local time on Monday after further testing.\n\n\"The latest test results confirm that Seine water quality levels at the triathlon venue have improved in recent hours, with forward looking analysis indicating that water quality will be within the levels acceptable by World Triathlon,\" World Triathlon and the Paris Games Organising Committee said in a statement.\n\n\"As a result, World Triathlon has taken the decision this evening to go ahead with the competition.\" However, Belgium will not be competing after they were forced to withdraw their team as one of their athletes fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel, who swam in the River Seine during the women's triathlon on Wednesday, fell ill after the race and Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee (BOIC) announced they would be dropping out of the race as a result.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon must unfortunately announce that the 'Belgian Hammers' will not be starting the mixed relay at the Paris Olympic Games tomorrow,\" they said in a statement.\n\n\"The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage. Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nThe BOIC also appeared to criticise the event's organisers, adding: \"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for the next triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games.\n\n\"We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, the entourage and the supporters.\"\n\nAdrien Briffod has been replaced on the Swiss team by Simon Westermann due to a gastrointestinal infection, although they insist it is \"impossible to say\" whether his illness is linked to concerns over water quality.\n\nFollow all the action from the Paris Olympics with Mirror Sport's live blog\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. {"uri": "8259094733", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:04:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:04:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:03:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.rt.com/news/602121-belgian-triathlete-hospitalized-olympics/", "title": "Another triathlete hospitalized after Olympics swim in Seine  --  RT World News", "body": "The Belgian triathlon team has forfeited the mixed triathlon finals scheduled for Monday due to an athlete, Claire Michel, being hospitalized after swimming in the Seine River, the country's Olympic Committee has announced.\n\nThe sporting body took jabs at the Paris Olympics organizers, expressing hopes \"that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions,\" and that there will be no more \"uncertainty\" for athletes and support personnel.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon must unfortunately announce that the 'Belgian Hammers' will not be starting the mixed relay at the Paris Olympic Games tomorrow. The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage,\" the committee said in a statement.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition,\" it added.\n\nWhile the committee did not elaborate, local media reports have suggested that Michel, who has been hospitalized for four days already, was diagnosed with an E.coli bacterial infection. While the athlete apparently fell ill shortly after finishing 38th in the women's triathlon competition on Wednesday, it has not been positively established that she contracted the bacteria in the murky waters of the Seine.\n\nThe development comes after the Swiss triathlon team said it had to replace triathlete Adrien Briffod with Simon Westermann after the former contracted a gastrointestinal infection. The team noted it was still unclear whether Briffod's illness was related to the Seine.\n\nThe Belgian team has been highly critical of the condition of the Seine, with multiple athletes publicly speaking of their experience. \"While swimming under the bridge, I felt and saw things that we shouldn't think about too much,\" Jolien Vermeylen, who finished 24th in Wednesday's event, said, adding that the waters did not exactly taste like \"Coca-Cola or Sprite.\"\n\n\"The Seine has been dirty for a hundred years, so they can't say the safety of the athletes is a priority,\" she claimed.\n\nThe water condition of the highly-polluted river had been a source of widespread concern long before the Games. A $1.5 billion project aimed at cleaning up the Seine yielded mixed results at best and was marred by various mishaps, including the release of a large quantity of sewage into the river shortly before the Olympics.\n\nThe French authorities, however, insisted on holding open-water competitions on the Seine, with several senior officials, including French Sports Minister Amelie Oudea-Castera and Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo, taking a swim in the river to demonstrate that it is safe. President Emmanuel Macron, who had also made a half-hearted pledge to take a dip, however, ultimately abstained from doing so.", "source": {"uri": "rt.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "RT"}, {"uri": "8259557314", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:41:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:41:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:39:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/olympic-triathlon-mixed-relay-gets-underway-with-swims-in-the-seine-amid-water-quality-concerns/article_515d3b6a-b180-5e67-94b2-1b387707f227.html", "title": "Olympic triathlon mixed relay gets underway with swims in the Seine amid water quality concerns", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Olympic triathletes plunged into the Seine River Monday morning as the mixed relay event got underway after organizers said the bacteria levels in the long-polluted Paris waterway were at acceptable levels.\n\nThe plan to hold the swimming portion of the triathlons and the marathon swimming events in the Seine was an ambitious one. Swimming in the river has, with some exceptions, been off-limits since 1923 because it has been too toxic.\n\nRepresentatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities met Sunday night to review water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over the preceding hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon by Monday morning, they said in a statement.\n\nThe decision to allow the event to go forward with swims in the Seine came after Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon after one of its competitors who swam in the river last week fell ill. It was not clear whether her illness had anything to do with her swim in the Seine.\n\nParis spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) on infrastructure improvements to clean up the river that flows through its center. That included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nHeavy rains that have fallen off and on during the Games have caused headaches for organizers as they result in elevated levels of fecal bacteria, including E. coli and enterococci, flowing into the river. Drenching rains fell Thursday night, but conditions had otherwise been dry except for light rain Saturday evening. The sun shone brightly as the race unfolded Monday and athletes said organizers reassured them that there were no concerns with water quality.\n\nOrganizers have continued to express confidence that warm temperatures and the sun's ultraviolet rays would combine to kill enough of the germs ahead of each event set to include a swim in the Seine.\n\nAthletes swam in the river for the men's and women's individual triathlons Wednesday, though the men's race had been delayed by a day because of the water quality. Elevated bacteria levels in the waterway have caused cancellations of the swimming portion of training sessions for the relay event.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nThe triathlon mixed relay involves four-person teams made up of two men and two women, with each athlete swimming for 300 meters (yards), cycling for 6.8 kilometers (4.2 miles) and running for 2 kilometers (1.2 miles).\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", {"uri": "2024-08-444142975", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:29:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:29:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:09:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-08-05/olympic-triathlon-mixed-relay-gets-underway-with-swims-in-the-seine-amid-water-quality-concerns", "title": "Olympic Triathlon Mixed Relay Gets Underway With Swims in the Seine Amid Water Quality Concerns", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Olympic triathletes plunged into the Seine River Monday morning as the mixed relay event got underway after days of uncertainty over water quality in the long-polluted Paris waterway.\n\nThe plan to hold the swimming portion of the triathlons and the marathon swimming events in the Seine was an ambitious one. Swimming in the river has, with some exceptions, been off-limits since 1923 because it has been too toxic.\n\nRepresentatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities met Sunday night to review water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over the preceding hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon by Monday morning, they said in a statement.\n\nThe decision to allow the event to go forward with swims in the Seine came after Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon after one of its competitors who swam in the river last week fell ill. It was not clear whether her illness had anything to do with her swim in the Seine.\n\nParis spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) on infrastructure improvements to clean up the river that flows through its center. That included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nHeavy rains that have fallen off and on during the Games have caused headaches for organizers as they result in elevated levels of fecal bacteria, including E. coli and enterococci, flowing into the river.\n\nBut organizers have continued to express confidence that warm temperatures and the sun's ultraviolet rays would combine to kill enough of the germs ahead of each event set to include a swim in the Seine.\n\nAthletes swam in the river for the men's and women's individual triathlons Wednesday, though the men's race had been delayed by a day because of the water quality. Elevated bacteria levels in the waterway have caused cancellations of the swimming portion of training sessions for the relay event.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nThe triathlon mixed relay involves four-person teams made up of two men and two women, with each athlete swimming for 300 meters (yards), cycling for 6.8 kilometers (4.2 miles) and running for 2 kilometers (1.2 miles).\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-08-444169194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:00:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:00:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:48:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.beaumontenterprise.com/sports/article/olympic-triathlon-mixed-relay-gets-underway-with-19619919.php", "title": "Olympic triathlon mixed relay gets underway with swims in the Seine amid water quality concerns", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Olympic triathletes plunged into the Seine River Monday morning as the mixed relay event got underway after organizers said the bacteria levels in the long-polluted Paris waterway were at acceptable levels.\n\nThe plan to hold the swimming portion of the triathlons and the marathon swimming events in the Seine was an ambitious one. Swimming in the river has, with some exceptions, been off-limits since 1923 because it has been too toxic.\n\nRepresentatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities met Sunday night to review water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over the preceding hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon by Monday morning, they said in a statement.\n\nThe decision to allow the event to go forward with swims in the Seine came after Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon after one of its competitors who swam in the river last week fell ill. It was not clear whether her illness had anything to do with her swim in the Seine.\n\nParis spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) on infrastructure improvements to clean up the river that flows through its center. That included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nHeavy rains that have fallen off and on during the Games have caused headaches for organizers as they result in elevated levels of fecal bacteria, including E. coli and enterococci, flowing into the river. Drenching rains fell Thursday night, but conditions had otherwise been dry except for light rain Saturday evening. The sun shone brightly as the race unfolded Monday and athletes said organizers reassured them that there were no concerns with water quality.\n\nOrganizers have continued to express confidence that warm temperatures and the sun's ultraviolet rays would combine to kill enough of the germs ahead of each event set to include a swim in the Seine.\n\nAthletes swam in the river for the men's and women's individual triathlons Wednesday, though the men's race had been delayed by a day because of the water quality. Elevated bacteria levels in the waterway have caused cancellations of the swimming portion of training sessions for the relay event.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nThe triathlon mixed relay involves four-person teams made up of two men and two women, with each athlete swimming for 300 meters (yards), cycling for 6.8 kilometers (4.2 miles) and running for 2 kilometers (1.2 miles).", "source": {"uri": "beaumontenterprise.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8259532507", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:20:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:20:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:19:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/ap-paris-international-olympic-committee-belgium-european-union-b2591185.html", "title": "Olympic triathlon mixed relay gets underway with swims in the Seine amid water quality concerns", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nOlympic triathletes plunged into the Seine River Monday morning as the mixed relay event got underway after days of uncertainty over water quality in the long-polluted Paris waterway.\n\nThe plan to hold the swimming portion of the triathlons and the marathon swimming events in the Seine was an ambitious one. Swimming in the river has, with some exceptions, been off-limits since 1923 because it has been too toxic.\n\nRepresentatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities met Sunday night to review water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over the preceding hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon by Monday morning, they said in a statement.\n\nThe decision to allow the event to go forward with swims in the Seine came after Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon after one of its competitors who swam in the river last week fell ill. It was not clear whether her illness had anything to do with her swim in the Seine.\n\nParis spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) on infrastructure improvements to clean up the river that flows through its center. That included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nHeavy rains that have fallen off and on during the Games have caused headaches for organizers as they result in elevated levels of fecal bacteria, including E. coli and enterococci, flowing into the river.\n\nBut organizers have continued to express confidence that warm temperatures and the sun's ultraviolet rays would combine to kill enough of the germs ahead of each event set to include a swim in the Seine.\n\nAthletes swam in the river for the men's and women's individual triathlons Wednesday, though the men's race had been delayed by a day because of the water quality. Elevated bacteria levels in the waterway have caused cancellations of the swimming portion of training sessions for the relay event.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nThe triathlon mixed relay involves four-person teams made up of two men and two women, with each athlete swimming for 300 meters (yards), cycling for 6.8 kilometers (4.2 miles) and running for 2 kilometers (1.2 miles).\n\n___\n\nAP Olympics: The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage,\" the committee said in a statement.\n\n\"Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition,\" it added.\n\nWhile the committee did not elaborate, local media reports have suggested that Michel, who has been hospitalized for four days already, was diagnosed with an E.coli bacterial infection. While the athlete apparently fell ill shortly after finishing 38th in the women's triathlon competition on Wednesday, it has not been positively established that she contracted the bacteria in the murky waters of the Seine.\n\nThe development comes after the Swiss triathlon team said it had to replace triathlete Adrien Briffod with Simon Westermann after the former contracted a gastrointestinal infection. The team noted it was still unclear whether Briffod's illness was related to the Seine.\n\nRead more: Trump agrees to Fox News debate with Harris on Sept 4\n\nThe Belgian team has been highly critical of the condition of the Seine, with multiple athletes publicly speaking of their experience. \"While swimming under the bridge, I felt and saw things that we shouldn't think about too much,\" Jolien Vermeylen, who finished 24th in Wednesday's event, said, adding that the waters did not exactly taste like \"Coca-Cola or Sprite.\"\n\n\"The Seine has been dirty for a hundred years, so they can't say the safety of the athletes is a priority,\" she claimed.\n\nThe water condition of the highly-polluted river had been a source of widespread concern long before the Games. A $1.5 billion project aimed at cleaning up the Seine yielded mixed results at best and was marred by various mishaps, including the release of a large quantity of sewage into the river shortly before the Olympics.\n\nThe French authorities, however, insisted on holding open-water competitions on the Seine, with several senior officials, including French Sports Minister Amelie Oudea-Castera and Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo, taking a swim in the river to demonstrate that it is safe. {"uri": "2024-08-444358476", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:59:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:59:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:59:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsParis/528536.aspx", "title": "Olympic triathlon mixed relay gets underway with swims in the Seine amid water quality concerns", "body": "The plan to hold the swimming portion of the triathlons and the marathon swimming events in the Seine was an ambitious one. Swimming in the river has, with some exceptions, been off-limits since 1923 because it has been too toxic.\n\nRepresentatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities met Sunday night to review water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over the preceding hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon by Monday morning, they said in a statement.\n\nThe decision to allow the event to go forward with swims in the Seine came after Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon after one of its competitors who swam in the river last week fell ill. It was not clear whether her illness had anything to do with her swim in the Seine.\n\nParis spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) on infrastructure improvements to clean up the river that flows through its center. That included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nHeavy rains that have fallen off and on during the Games have caused headaches for organizers as they result in elevated levels of fecal bacteria, including E. coli and enterococci, flowing into the river. Drenching rains fell Thursday night, but conditions had otherwise been dry except for light rain Saturday evening. The sun shone brightly as the race unfolded Monday and athletes said organizers reassured them that there were no concerns with water quality.\n\nOrganizers have continued to express confidence that warm temperatures and the sun's ultraviolet rays would combine to kill enough of the germs ahead of each event set to include a swim in the Seine.\n\nAthletes swam in the river for the men's and women's individual triathlons Wednesday, though the men's race had been delayed by a day because of the water quality. Elevated bacteria levels in the waterway have caused cancellations of the swimming portion of training sessions for the relay event.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nThe triathlon mixed relay involves four-person teams made up of two men and two women, with each athlete swimming for 300 meters (yards), cycling for 6.8 kilometers (4.2 miles) and running for 2 kilometers (1.2 miles).", "source": {"uri": "english.ahram.org.eg", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-08-443819918", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:04:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:04:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:59:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/olympics/2024/08/04/olympic-triathlete-sick-seine-swim-belgium/", "title": "Belgium won't compete in triathlon in Seine after athlete falls ill", "body": "Sorry, a summary is not available for this article at this time. Please try again later.\n\nBelgium's mixed triathlon team has pulled out of Monday's race because one of its athletes, who raced in the women's triathlon in the Seine last week, is ill, the country's Olympic committee said, in a statement that called into question organizers' handling of the events.\n\nThe triathlete, 35-year-old Claire Michel, finished 38th in Wednesday's women's individual triathlon. Belgian officials did not provide any details about Michel's illness or directly connect it to the event, which took place despite multiple training sessions being canceled and the men's event being postponed because of pollution in the river.\n\nParis and other municipalities spent 1.4 billion euros on a project to clean the notoriously polluted Seine and make it swimmable for the Olympics.\n\nIn a statement Sunday, Belgium's Olympic Committee said it and Belgian Triathlon \"hope that lessons will be learned for the next triathlon competitions at the Olympic Games.\n\nplayPlay now\n\nNaN min\n\nFollow on\n\nPodcast episode\n\nSpotify\n\nApple\n\nGoogle\n\nAmazon\n\n\"We are thinking here of the guarantee of training days, competition days and the competition format which must be clarified in advance and ensure that there is no uncertainty for the athletes, their entourage and the supporters,\" the statement continued.\n\nOfficials at World Triathlon, which oversees Olympic triathlons, and the International Olympic Committee did not immediately respond to messages seeking comment.\n\nIn the days leading up to last week's triathlons, World Triathlon and Paris 2024 officials cancelled practice sessions in the river because E. Coli readings were too high for World Triathlon's standards. Two days of rain on the Games' first weekend had overloaded the city's sewers with rain runoff, a common problem in Paris. Several rainstorms have again raised the river's pollution levels, and World Triathlon cancelled another swim practice Sunday.\n\nAfter last week's triathlons, many of the competitors brushed off fears over the water's quality, saying they were more concerned by the river's rapid current, which left at least one woman saying she was unsure she could finish the race.\n\nOthers were glib. American Taylor Knibb joked with reporters after the women's triathlon, offering to \"grab a cup\" if anyone wished to taste the Seine water.\n\nAt a press conference before the Olympics began, her male teammate Seth Rider said he was preparing to swim in the Seine by strengthening his \"E. coli threshold by exposing myself to a bit of E. coli in your day-to-day life,\" adding that he was no longer washing his hands after going to the bathroom.\" He later said he was joking.\n\nAt a press conference here Sunday, Paris 2024 communications director Anne Descamps said water quality tests are still being conducted daily. She added that the decision to cancel Sunday's mixed triathlon swim training came after examining test results from Saturday, and that a decision on Monday's race would be made that morning.", {"uri": "2024-08-444435201", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:06:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:06:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:03:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/germany-wins-illness-affected-olympic-mixed-team-relay-triathlon/article_fcb53ab2-c729-54fd-9503-46822469e7c2.html", "title": "Germany wins illness-affected Olympic mixed team relay triathlon", "body": "Germany won gold in the mixed triathlon relay on Monday at the Paris Olympics, with the event disrupted by illnesses that saw at least three teams report sick team members who swam in the River Seine last week.\n\nIn a thrilling climax to the team race through central Paris, Germany's Laura Lindemann won a sprint finish, narrowly edging out Taylor Knibb from the United States in second and Beth Potter from Britain in third.\n\nThe Belgian team did not race at all after their athlete Claire Michel fell sick, reportedly with E.Coli, having swum in the Seine during the women's individual triathlon last Wednesday.\n\nThe Swiss team also had to bring in a replacement after their racer Adrien Briffod suffered a gastrointestinal infection, while Norwegian competitor Vetle Bergsvik Thorn told AFP he too had been stricken with a stomach bug after the men's race last week.\n\n\"I was sick for about 12 hours, overnight from Friday to Saturday,\" he said. \"I don't know if it was food poisoning or from the Seine. Obviously it wasn't the best preparation for today.\"\n\nThe relay is a four-person sprint triathlon, with Monday's race seeing two men and two women completing a 300-metre swim in the Seine, a seven-kilometre (4.3-mile) bike ride through central Paris and a 1.8 km run.\n\nThe Seine has been the focus of attention during the Paris triathlon events with the waterway consistently failing water quality tests despite a 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) upgrade to improve the Paris sewerage and water treatment systems.\n\nThe men's race last week had to be delayed by 24 hours and no training has been possible since the start of the Games on July 28, with many athletes again surprised by the strength of the current on Monday.\n\n\"It takes some courage to swim and the ability of a good swimmer to navigate it,\" victorious German Tim Hellwig told reporters.\n\nOrganisers have stressed that the illnesses cannot be attributed to the Seine and Hellwig said he felt confident in the water tests overseen by international governing body World Triathlon.\n\n\"No-one was afraid to jump in. We were all happy to have a race,\" he added, saying that he woke up fine after last week's men's event.\n\n\"If like 99 percent of the athletes don't have any problems, I think it's fine,\" he said.\n\n- Safety -\n\nOn the eve of Monday's relay, the Belgian National Olympic Committee (COIB) revealed that Michel had fallen sick in a statement that also criticised the organisation of the triathlon at the Paris Games.\n\n\"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that the lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympics,\" the committee said.\n\nOther racers have also expressed frustration that decisions on whether the river could be used for the training and competitions were taken in the middle of the night, while organisers had threatened to scrap the swimming leg completely if the river remained too dirty.\n\n\"I don't want to be too negative. However I do think if a situation like this happens again at the Olympics, they should have a backup venue,\" US silver medallist Morgan Pearson told reporters.\n\n\"I don't think any of us are like 'I'm not going to race because of the chance of E. coli'. It's the Olympics. But that shows the liberty they took,\" he added.\n\nHeavy rainstorms overwhelm Paris's sewerage system, leading to discharges of untreated waste water that send levels of bacteria such as E.Coli spiking.\n\nParis has been drenched by two major downpours since the Olympics started, on the night of the opening ceremony and again last Thursday evening.\n\nThe Paris 2024 organising committee said in a statement that testing on the day of the men's and women's triathlon last week had shown that the quality of the water was \"very good\" based on World Triathlon's criteria.\n\n\"The decision on whether to proceed with an event is taken by the international federation, World Triathlon, in coordination with Paris 2024, and based on the test results and a range of (notably health) criteria,\" it said.\n\n\"Paris 2024 wishes to remind everyone that the health and wellbeing of athletes is our top priority,\" it added.\n\nadp/gj\n\nMore from this section\n\nHarris has secured enough Democratic delegate votes to become their party's nominee, chair says\n\nSET Enterprises launches 340b covered entity suspicious purchase identification service for pharmaceutical and biological Wednesday and Thursday again caused levels of bacteria in the water to rise.\n\nThe men's race was changed from Tuesday to Wednesday, the same day as the women's competition, earlier this week, with athletes unable to swim in the river until the day of the race.\n\nBritain's athletes are all understood to have avoided any ill effects from swimming in the water but they now face more disruption to their preparations, with swim familiarisation sessions cancelled on Saturday and Sunday.\n\nFollowing a meeting on Saturday evening, a statement was issued by organisers on Sunday morning, which read: {"uri": "8259891093", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:27:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:27:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:26:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/germany-wins-illness-affected-olympic-mixed-team-relay-triathlon/article_916ac1ab-fec9-5319-b758-907b4334861c.html", "title": "Germany wins illness-affected Olympic mixed team relay triathlon", "body": "Germany won gold in the mixed triathlon relay on Monday at the Paris Olympics, with the event disrupted by illnesses that saw at least three teams report sick team members who swam in the River Seine last week.\n\nIn a thrilling climax to the team race through central Paris, Germany's Laura Lindemann won a sprint finish, narrowly edging out Taylor Knibb from the United States in second and Beth Potter from Britain in third.\n\nThe Belgian team did not race at all after their athlete Claire Michel fell sick, reportedly with E.Coli, having swum in the Seine during the women's individual triathlon last Wednesday.\n\nThe Swiss team also had to bring in a replacement after their racer Adrien Briffod suffered a gastrointestinal infection, while Norwegian competitor Vetle Bergsvik Thorn told AFP he too had been stricken with a stomach bug after the men's race last week.\n\n\"I was sick for about 12 hours, overnight from Friday to Saturday,\" he said. \"I don't know if it was food poisoning or from the Seine. Obviously it wasn't the best preparation for today.\"\n\nThe relay is a four-person sprint triathlon, with Monday's race seeing two men and two women completing a 300-metre swim in the Seine, a seven-kilometre (4.3-mile) bike ride through central Paris and a 1.8 km run.\n\nThe Seine has been the focus of attention during the Paris triathlon events with the waterway consistently failing water quality tests despite a 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) upgrade to improve the Paris sewerage and water treatment systems.\n\nThe men's race last week had to be delayed by 24 hours and no training has been possible since the start of the Games on July 28, with many athletes again surprised by the strength of the current on Monday.\n\n\"It takes some courage to swim and the ability of a good swimmer to navigate it,\" victorious German Tim Hellwig told reporters.\n\nOrganisers have stressed that the illnesses cannot be attributed to the Seine and Hellwig said he felt confident in the water tests overseen by international governing body World Triathlon.\n\n\"No-one was afraid to jump in. We were all happy to have a race,\" he added, saying that he woke up fine after last week's men's event.\n\n\"If like 99 percent of the athletes don't have any problems, I think it's fine,\" he said.\n\nMore from this section Harris campaign raises hulking $310 mn in July Colombia, Guatemala learn from each other in rainforest preservation No.1 Swiatek withdraws from WTA Toronto event due to fatigue - Safety -\n\nOn the eve of Monday's relay, the Belgian National Olympic Committee (COIB) revealed that Michel had fallen sick in a statement that also criticised the organisation of the triathlon at the Paris Games.\n\n\"The COIB and Belgian Triathlon hope that the lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions at the Olympics,\" the committee said.\n\nOther racers have also expressed frustration that decisions on whether the river could be used for the training and competitions were taken in the middle of the night, while organisers had threatened to scrap the swimming leg completely if the river remained too dirty.\n\n\"I don't want to be too negative. However I do think if a situation like this happens again at the Olympics, they should have a backup venue,\" US silver medallist Morgan Pearson told reporters.\n\n\"I don't think any of us are like 'I'm not going to race because of the chance of E. coli'. It's the Olympics. But that shows the liberty they took,\" he added.\n\nHeavy rainstorms overwhelm Paris's sewerage system, leading to discharges of untreated waste water that send levels of bacteria such as E.Coli spiking.\n\nParis has been drenched by two major downpours since the Olympics started, on the night of the opening ceremony and again last Thursday evening.\n\nThe Paris 2024 organising committee said in a statement that testing on the day of the men's and women's triathlon last week had shown that the quality of the water was \"very good\" based on World Triathlon's criteria.\n\n\"The decision on whether to proceed with an event is taken by the international federation, World Triathlon, in coordination with Paris 2024, and based on the test results and a range of (notably health) criteria,\" it said.\n\n\"Paris 2024 wishes to remind everyone that the health and wellbeing of athletes is our top priority,\" it added.\n\nadp/gj", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8259828773", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:48:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:48:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:47:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://thewillnews.com/water-quality-concerns-force-belgian-triathlon-team-withdrawal/", "title": "Water Quality Concerns Force Belgian Triathlon Team Withdrawal", "body": "August 05, (THEWILL) - Belgium has withdrawn from the Olympic mixed relay triathlon after one of its athletes fell ill following the women's triathlon event.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the River Seine on Wednesday, was taken to the Olympic Village Polyclinic for treatment before returning to her room.\n\nThe Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee (BOIC) announced the decision on Sunday, citing concerns about water quality in the Seine. This withdrawal comes after organisers cancelled swimming portions of familiarisation sessions for the mixed relay due to high pollution levels.\n\nThe Seine's water quality has been a significant issue leading up to the Paris 2024 Olympics. Despite years of preparation and substantial investment in water treatment technology, elevated bacteria levels caused disruptions to the triathlon schedule earlier in the week.\n\nThe BOIC has called for lessons to be learned from this experience, emphasising the need for clearer competition formats and guaranteed training days. They stressed the importance of eliminating uncertainty for athletes, support staff, and spectators.\n\nThe mixed relay triathlon, a relatively new Olympic event first introduced in Tokyo, is scheduled for Monday. It involves four team members each completing a sprint triathlon. The withdrawal of the Belgian team is a setback for the event and raises further questions about the Seine's suitability for Olympic competition.", "source": {"uri": "thewillnews.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8260029170", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:54:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:54:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:53:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://wsbt.com/news/entertainment/claire-michel-sick-seine-river-olympics-triathlete-reportedly-hospitalized-e-coli-infection-following-swim-team-pulls-out-event-cincinnati-2024-paris-games-international-olympic-committee-safe-safety-concerns-bacteria-life-changing-allegations-swimming", "title": "Olympics triathlete sick following swim in Seine River, team pulls out of event", "body": "PARIS (WKRC) - An Olympics triathlete was reportedly hospitalized after last Wednesday's women's triathlon event.\n\nAccording to USA Today, citing Belgium's national Olympic committee, 35-year-old Claire Michel became sick sometime after she swam in the Seine River. Per the outlet, Michel's illness led to Belgium's triathlon team pulling out of Monday's mixed relay event in the Seine.\n\nMichel finished 38th in last Wednesday's women's triathlon event.\n\nThe team issued a statement on the same day Olympic organizers canceled a training session for the swimming leg of the race due to the Seine failing to meet water-quality tests.\n\nThe Belgian newspaper De Standaard reported that Michel has been hospitalized with an E. coli infection. That report has not been confirmed elsewhere, however.\n\nThe Belgian Olympic Committee declined to comment on the claims, with the International Olympic Committee and World Triathlon sport's international body telling USA Today that they were not aware of the report.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon must unfortunately announce that the 'Belgian Hammers' will not be starting the mixed relay at the Paris Olympic Games tomorrow,\" reads a statement from the country, obtained byThe New York Post. \"The decision, like this communication, was taken in consultation with the athletes and their entourage. Claire Michel, a member of the relay, is unfortunately ill and must withdraw from the competition.\"\n\nAccording to CBS News, tests taken back in June indicated that E. coli levels in the Seine were ten times above acceptable levels. The bacteria is typically linked to fecal matter and can cause infections, such as urinary tract infections, diarrhea, sepsis and pneumonia.\n\nAlthough there have been concerns about the Seine's cleanliness, organizers gave the go-ahead for triathlon events after data showed the river's water quality had finally reached acceptable levels.\n\nIt comes after Belgium triathlete Jolien Vermeylen told Flemish television outlet VTM that she had \"felt and saw things that we shouldn't think about\" while swimming under a bridge during last Wednesday's event.\n\n\"The Seine has been dirty for a hundred years, so they can't say that the safety of the athletes is a priority,\" Vermeylen told the outlet.\n\nCassandre Beaugrand, who is representing France, won gold in the event, Julie Derron of Switzerland took home silver, while Beth Potter of Britain won bronze.", "source": {"uri": "wsbt.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WSBT"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443599489", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "13:03:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T13:03:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T12:01:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/health/more-olympians-are-set-to-compete-in-the-seine-river-heres-the-latest-on-water-quality-concerns/", "title": "More Olympians are set to compete in the Seine River. Here's the latest on water quality concerns", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- At the Paris Olympics, whether the water quality in the Seine River is safe enough to host some swimming events has been a major question.\n\nBacteria levels in the river fluctuate constantly, and daily water samples are tested so organizers can assess the risk and determine whether swims in the long-polluted Paris waterway should go forward.\n\nTriathletes raced in the river Wednesday, and testing will determine whether upcoming competitions will happen as planned, including the triathlon mixed relay Monday and the marathon swimming races scheduled for Thursday and Friday.\n\nHere are some things to know about water quality testing in the Seine:\n\nWhy do bacteria levels matter?\n\nHigh levels of E. coli and enterococci indicate sewage or fecal pollution in the water. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous.\n\nEven a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or intestines can result.\n\nHow susceptible a person is to falling ill from E. coli exposure depends on several factors, chief among them a person's age and general health.\n\n\"Generally speaking, the healthier you are, the more likely you're going to be to withstand any sort of pathogen,\" said Brian Rahm, a biological and environmental engineering expert at Cornell University.\n\nSometimes it's not even the E. coli itself that's cause for worry, Rahm said. \"When we see E. coli in the water, it indicates that other types of pathogens and other bacteria, viruses may also be in the water.\"\n\nTesting helps organizers assess the risk to athletes, but it's difficult to quantify the exact risk using that data, said Metin Duran, a professor of civil and environmental engineering at Villanova University.\n\n\"Unfortunately, there is not much to do prior to exposure to reduce the risk,\" Duran said.\n\nSwiss officials said Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who competed in the Seine three days earlier, fell ill with a stomach infection. But they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to his swim in the river and that the other delegations told them none of their triathletes reported stomach problems.\n\nWhy do bacteria levels change?\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is linked closely to the weather. Heavy rains cause wastewater and runoff to flow into the river, causing bacteria levels to rise, while the sun's ultraviolet rays can kill the bacteria.\n\nAnd Paris has seen several downpours during the Games so far.\n\nTo deal with those contingencies, Paris made 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements ahead of the Olympics, including building a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from entering the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Deputy Mayor Pierre Rabadan said those improvements have made a big difference.\n\n\"We'll never keep rain events from having an impact on the water quality. That's not possible,\" he said. \"What we've done will allow us to return to a water quality that is satisfactory and good, like it was for the triathlon.\"\n\nOrganizers have canceled multiple test swims this weekend and last week meant to let triathletes familiarize themselves with the course over water quality concerns following rain. The men's triathlon was postponed by a day, then went ahead Wednesday, the same day as the women's race.\n\nFor Monday's triathlon mixed relay, if the water quality isn't at safe levels, organizers can delay to Tuesday. If concerns persist, the swim will be scrapped and the athletes will just compete in the running and cycling portions of the race.\n\nDecisions on whether to cancel an event are made in the wee hours of the morning on race day, and that's what is expected to happen for Monday's triathlon mixed relay. Organizers consider samples taken from the river 21 and a half hours earlier to allow time for cultures to develop in a lab.\n\nRabadan said infrastructure improvements prevent wastewater from flowing into the Seine. It rained Wednesday as the triathletes competed. Wastewater entering the river upstream would take several hours to reach Paris, meaning that the water quality levels were still safe at the time of that race, he said.\n\nSince then, there was a heavy downpour Thursday night and it also rained Saturday evening.\n\nParis 2024 spokesperson Anne Descamps said Sunday that organizers are \"hopeful that we can organize the competition tomorrow, and we will take the decision, as planned, tomorrow morning.\"\n\nWhat do the tests consider?\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nWorld Triathlon in an email called the European Union's 2006 directive \"the most complete guidelines for bathing water,\" based on the range of factors it takes into account. Other organizations, including the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, set a limit of 126 units per 100 milliliters of water and say that higher levels aren't suitable for recreational use.\n\nIn deciding whether events can be held in the river, World Triathlon's medical committee said it considers water quality analysis, sanitary inspection and the weather forecast.\n\nA day after Wednesday's competitions in the Seine, data released by World Triathlon showed that a sample taken at 6 a.m. Wednesday at the Pont Alexandre III, the bridge where the swimming segment began and ended, showed a level of 249 units. Samples from other points along the course were at similar levels.\n\nAre the tests used during the Games sufficient?\n\nDan Angelescu, founder and CEO of Fluidion, a Paris and Los Angeles-based water monitoring tech company, says the tests have \"shortcomings\" and \"undercount severely the bacteria.\"\n\nFluidion is testing the water several times a day, and Angelescu said, \"What we see is that water quality is not as good as those measurement data that the city publishes,\" resulting in \"an underestimation of the actual risk.\"\n\nThe company measures both \"free floating\" bacteria in the water and takes a \"comprehensive\" level that Angelescu says also includes bacteria attached to fecal or sediment particles. He said the comprehensive count provides a more complete picture than the lab test the city is using.\n\nHe likened it to watching a busy road with pedestrians, motorcycles, cars and buses and trying to count all the people. The city's method, he said, is akin to counting from a helicopter and weighting each person or vehicle equally because you can't see how many people are inside each car or bus. He says his comprehensive test is more like a police officer stopping each vehicle and counting each person inside the cars and buses to get a complete count.\n\nAngelescu said he discussed these discrepancies with city officials and that they decided to continue with the standard laboratory method they had been using, which complies with regulations. That was a \"fair decision in view of the regulations,\" he said. \"The problem is the regulations are wrong.\"\n\nRahm of Cornell University said that, ultimately, \"from a public health perspective. it doesn't matter whether it's free flowing or trapped inside a dirt particle. It's going to get inside your body one way or another.\"\n\n___\n\nNaishadham reported from Washington. AP journalists Jeffrey Schaeffer in Alfortville, France, and Angela Charlton, John Leicester and Ahmed Hatem in Paris contributed.\n\n___\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "seattletimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Seattle Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kate_brumback@seattletimes.com", "name": {"uri": "8259004313", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:05:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:05:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:04:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/belgium-olympic-team-forfeit-paris-triathlon-due-to-ecoli-infection/", "title": "Belgium Olympic athlete 'hospitalised with E. coli infection' after swimming in Seine River", "body": "Highlights Belgium have withdrawn from the Paris 2024 Olympic triathlon after competitor Claire Michel allegedly contracted E. coli. River Seine pollution has already led to the cancellation of practice sessions, while there is a possibility the triathlon will be downgraded to a duathlon format. Organizers continue to be criticised for ongoing E. coli issues in the historic but unclean river.\n\nBelgium has pulled out of Monday's in-doubt triathlon at the 2024 Paris Olympics - with a member of their team hospitalised for four days after swimming in the River Seine.\n\nEarly reports from Daily Mail indicate that Claire Michel has been ''hospitalised with an E. coli infection'. The bacteria can lead to various severe stomach and intestinal problems. As such, more criticism towards the Games officials has emerged as serious questions continue to be asked about the suitability of a river that has not been fit for human use for 100 years.\n\nA full Seine cleanup was proposed as part of Paris's bid to hold the Olympics, as a way for the city's leaders to show that holding the games would \"ensure that our candidacy is useful to Parisians.\" But while the work began in 2016, and over \u00a31billion has been spent on the operation so far, there's still issues with its health and safety.\n\nRelated 'I Swam in River Seine at The Olympics - I Saw Things I Don't Want to Think About'\n\nTriathletes were forced to swim in the highly polluted River Seine, which had previously been banned for 100 years\n\n1 Belgium Pull out of Triathlon A practice session was cancelled on Sunday amid pollution fears\n\nA practice session was cancelled on Sunday after rainfall in Paris pushed pollution in the water beyond permitted levels amid fears that the River Seine still doesn't meet health and safety requirements. Organisers were due to make a call on whether the mixed relay would go ahead this morning - just hours before the event was due to start. Tomorrow has been pencilled in as a back-up day.\n\nBut while the men's triathlon, won by Britain's Alex Yee, ended up being pushed back and both the men's and women's familiarisation sessions were postponed earlier in the Games, more embarassment seems to be heaping on top of the organisers, who are yet to admit defeat in their hopes of reliving Olympic heritage by using the historic venue.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: The River Seine in Paris was last used for the Olympics during the 1900 Summer Games. It served as the venue for events such as swimming and rowing. The Seine's waters were utilized for various competitions, with swimmers racing against the backdrop of one of the world's most famous rivers.\n\nLevels of E. coli have regularly been deemed too high for events this Summer, and the latest episode in an embarrassing saga has forced the Belgian Committee to take a stand against the ongoing issue. Michel's fellow Jolien Vermeylen recently slammed organised, saying they don't care for the 'safety of the athletes'.\n\nRelated Olympic Triathlete Vomits After Swimming in River Seine\n\nCanadian triathlete Tyler Mislawchuk was captured immediately throwing up after he crossed the finishing line at the Paris Olympics.\n\n2 Belgium's Statement They hope that lessons will finally be learnt\n\nThe statement released on Sunday read: \"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon unfortunately have to announce that the Belgian Hammers will not start in the Mixed Relay competition at the Paris Games tomorrow. This decision, as well as the communication about it, was taken in consultation with the athletes and the entourage.\n\n\"Claire Michel, one of the athletes in the mixed relay team, unfortunately has to withdraw from the competition due to illness. Claire Michel is a member of both the BOIC and World Triathlon Athlete Commissions. As an athlete representative, she is committed to continuously evaluating and improving conditions for athletes.\n\n\"The BOIC and Belgian Triathlon hope that lessons will be learned for future triathlon competitions. We are thinking of training days that can be guaranteed, competition days and formats that are clear in advance and circumstances that do not cause uncertainty among athletes, entourage and fans.\"\n\nAround a month before the Games started, tests from a monitoring group showed E. coli, which is linked to faeces and can cause diarrhoea, urinary tract infections, sepsis and pneumonia, was 10 times higher than acceptable levels. The Mixed Relay, scheduled to take part at 0800 local time on Monday, is currently under threat of postponement, and if the event cannot take place 24 hours after, then the race will be downgraded to duathlon (run/bike/run) format.", "source": {"uri": "givemesport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GiveMeSport"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claire_Michel", {"uri": "8259673759", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:06:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:06:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:05:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-olympic-triathlon-mixed-relay-gets-underway-with-swims-in-the-seine-amid-water-quality-concerns-6164771.html", "title": "Sports News | Olympic Triathlon Mixed Relay Gets Underway with Swims in the Seine Amid Water Quality Concerns | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. Olympic triathletes plunged into the Seine River Monday morning as the mixed relay event got underway after organizers said the bacteria levels in the long-polluted Paris waterway were at acceptable levels.\n\nParis, Aug 5 (AP) Olympic triathletes plunged into the Seine River Monday morning as the mixed relay event got underway after organizers said the bacteria levels in the long-polluted Paris waterway were at acceptable levels.\n\nThe plan to hold the swimming portion of the triathlons and the marathon swimming events in the Seine was an ambitious one. Swimming in the river has, with some exceptions, been off-limits since 1923 because it has been too toxic.\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024 Live Updates Day 10: India's Anantjeet Singh Naruka and Maheshwari Chauhan Live in Action Now.\n\nRepresentatives from World Triathlon and the International Olympic Committee along with Paris Games organizers and regional and weather authorities met Sunday night to review water tests. The results indicated the water quality at the triathlon site had improved over the preceding hours and would be within the limits mandated by World Triathlon by Monday morning, they said in a statement.\n\nThe decision to allow the event to go forward with swims in the Seine came after Belgium's Olympic committee announced Sunday that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon after one of its competitors who swam in the river last week fell ill. It was not clear whether her illness had anything to do with her swim in the Seine.\n\nAlso Read | Subhash Ghai Feels 'Blessed' As 'Taal' Theme Music Graces USA's World Aquatics Doha 2024 Performance.\n\nParis spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) on infrastructure improvements to clean up the river that flows through its center. That included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nHeavy rains that have fallen off and on during the Games have caused headaches for organizers as they result in elevated levels of fecal bacteria, including E. coli and enterococci, flowing into the river. Drenching rains fell Thursday night, but conditions had otherwise been dry except for light rain Saturday evening. The sun shone brightly as the race unfolded Monday and athletes said organizers reassured them that there were no concerns with water quality.\n\nOrganizers have continued to express confidence that warm temperatures and the sun's ultraviolet rays would combine to kill enough of the germs ahead of each event set to include a swim in the Seine.\n\nAthletes swam in the river for the men's and women's individual triathlons Wednesday, though the men's race had been delayed by a day because of the water quality. Elevated bacteria levels in the waterway have caused cancellations of the swimming portion of training sessions for the relay event.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria, including E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive assign qualitative values to a range of E. coli levels.\n\nUnder World Triathlon's guidelines, E. coli levels up to 1,000 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters can be considered \"good\" and can allow competitions to go forward.\n\nThe triathlon mixed relay involves four-person teams made up of two men and two women, with each athlete swimming for 300 meters (yards), cycling for 6.8 kilometers (4.2 miles) and running for 2 kilometers (1.2 miles).
